But withal to leaue the holy ghost, his deputy (as Tertullian Tertul. con. prax. calleth him) Ioh. 16. 13. to direct vs into all trueth: & to continue with vs, not, for a month, but Mat 28. 20. for euer, we neede not thirst so greedily for like discoueries. Againe, we denye not, but that as the spirite Ioh. 3. 8. bloweth where he list, as the power of Christ is neither stinted, nor confined within boundes, so when it pleaseth him, he may raise vp a prophet that shall tell what is to come, but after such a manner, as he raised Ioh. 11. 44. Lazarus from death: mary notwithstanding since we shall be pestered, wyth false prophetes (as our sauiour Christ warned vs) vnder the skynnes of Mat. 7, 15. Lambes, that is the weede of plainnesse and simplicity, which inwardly are rauening and deuouring woolues.

Since there were false Prophetes, once among you (sayth saint Peter) 2. Pet. 2, 2. Sicut & nunc, in vobis sunt magistri mendaces, euen as now ther are among you lying maisters, since as I prooued in another place, the deuyll can trāsforme himselfe into 2, Cor. 11, 14 an Angel of lyght, not for any leue he beares to heauen, but to prepare a way to spoyle on earth: wee cannot be to warie in distinguishing the ministers of lyght frō darknesse, trueth from errour, and lyes from prophecie. Saint Iohn aduiseth vs. 1. Iohn. 3, 4. Probare spiritus, to trye spirits whether they be of God or not: and S. Paule, so much esteemes this gyft. 1. Co. 12, 10. Discretionis spirituum, of discerning spirites, as he matcheth it with that of working miracles, we reade that God 2. Re. 16, 12. cōmaunded Semei to curse Dauid: againe Ezec. 14. 9. Prophetacum errauerit & loquutus fuerit verbum, ego Dominus decepi illum, when the Prophet hath erred, & sayd the word (sayth God by Exechiel) I the Lord haue deceyued him. To lyke effect he warranted the course which the 1 Reg. 22. 22 lying spirit, meāt to take in abusing Achab, with his whole consort of Prophetes, in those wordes, (o) Decipies & praeualebis. The same God, gaue ouer Ezechias lykewise, Vt 2. Par. 32, 31. tentaretur. Beside, in that short fourme of prayer which our sauiour hath set downe for vs in the Gospell, our request is, that he Nahu 6. 13. leade vs not into tentation, &c. Wherfore we are to note, out of a place in Deu. 13, 3. Deuteronomy, that God permitteth vs to be tempted oftentimès, & that for sundry causes: first, vt palam fiat an diligamus, in toto corde, in tota anima nostra, that it may be manifest, whether we looue with all our heart, and with all our soule. And (to the same effect) saint Paule hath set it downe, that 1. Cor, 11. 19. heresies must be, that they which are approoued may be manifest, another reason is, Vt 2. Thes. 2, 9. iudicentur omnes, qui non crediderunt veritati, that all they may be iudged, which haue not giuen credite to the truth. Thyrdly, Vt Tob. 2. 12. posteris detur exemplum patientiae nostrae, that an example of our sufferaunce maye bee transported, and conueyed to those that shall come after vs. Furthermore, that we may repayre more speedily to God, when the deuyll chaseth vs in most extremitie: and last of all, Vt Lact. de Orig. err. lib. 20. 18. habeat alios quos puniat, alois quos honoret, that he maye finde some to rewarde, and some to pnnishe. Wherevpon it is affirmed in the Iudg. 14. Iudges, that when Sampson went about to marrie with an Infidell, Parentes nesciebant quod res a Domino fieret, & quaereret occasionē contra Philisthim: his parents vnderstood not that thing was wrought by God, that by this meane he might picke a quarell against Philisthim.

When some shall say that heere, and there is Christe, when Antichrist himselfe shall come, according to the operation of Sathan, in all lying2. Thes. 2, 9. signes and woonders, &c. When the dayes shall be so daungerous, as faith cannot be found without some difficultie, and if those dayes were not catte off by mercie, the verie chosen and elect themselues, should
haue much a doo to shunne the trappe of guyle, then may we count him happy by the voyce of Christe, that persisteth to the finall ende of allTertul. contra. Marc. lib. 2. infirmitie. Fauos etiam vespae faciant, the Waspes make combes as well as Bees: and by the text it selfe it maye be gathered, that deuylles of the myddle sort might be cast out in the name of Belzebub, whome God reserueth by his mercie, In deuorationem, cui vult et, quando vult, to be deuowred by whome, and when it pleaseth him. All these assaults are strong, but yet God is faithfull, who wyll not suffer vs to bee tryedMatth. 9, 33. and tempted aboue our ability: Omnia autem possumus, in eo qui nos confortat, but we maye doo all in him that comfortes vs. But euen as4 Esdr. 5, 23. they which offered Sacrifice to fayned gods, with the fonde Arcadians, were transfourmed into one wilde beast or other: as they that tasted of that whorishe cuppe in the Reuelation, were consumed by the wrath of2. Cor. 1, 18 Phil. 4. 13. God, as Lottes wife, onely for looking backe, was turned into a stone of • alte: as none that hauing set theyr handes once to the plowe, drawe back againe, are apte for the kingdome of God: so they that giue them selues from trueth to lyes, are ten tymes worse then eyther brute beastsApoc. 17, 4. or stones, and hatch more monsters in the church of Christe, then euer Poetes coul • deuise out of the crotchettes of theyr gyddie fancies. If then the deuil by this sleight, in changing ct transfourming shapes and colours, as without the grace of God he may deceyue the best: and GodLuke. 9, 62 himselfe hath sometymes armed him for reproofe of our assured faith, which striue and skyrmishe, vnder the most royall ensigne of the crosse of Christe: wee must seeke out more certayne groundes of difference, betweene the Prophecies of GOD, and the deceytes of Sathan, if wee meane to be prepared against mischeefe, neyther is this matter difficult or hard, to those that labor in the word. For euē as God enflamed with a mercifull and tēder care of our soules health, hath specified the marks whereby the false Apostles may be noted and distincted, from the Pastours of the Church. So maye we iudge of Prophetes, by the same, so often as it pleaseth him to rayse vp any, in an extraordinarie manner.

FIrst, therefore I require that whosoeuer wyll be taken, and reputed as a lawfull Prophet, prooue his spirite to haue beene inspired from aboue: for, otherwise howe cunninglie soeuer it be vayled with a maske of guile, yet wyll it neyther carry weight nor colour with the godly. Of this minde was godly Ioseph, when he tolde the seruants of king Pharao, Dei esse interpretationem, that interpretation belongedGene. 40, 8. vnto God: and so lykewise was Daniel, referring all to God which foretelleth things to come: Mihi quoque non in sapiētia quae est in me, plus quam in cunctis viuentibus sacramentum hoc reuelatum est, &c. For this misterie (sayth he) was not reuealed vnto mee, in respect of anyDan. 2, 30. greater wisedome, then is in other men, &c. By Iob we are assured,
Inspirationem omnipotentis, dare intelligentiam, that the inspiration of the almighty giueth vnderstanding: so that we may prescribe withIohn. 32. 8. Amos, Partem super quam non pluit Dominus aresce • e, That the parte dooth parch and wyther, vpon which God letteth fall no droppes of hisAmos. 4. 7. fauour, Hoc primum intelligentes, &c. For, this must we first of al conceyue and vnderstand (sayth saint 2. Per. 1. 21. Peter) that no prophecie of Scripture, is made by priuate interpretation. For, not by the wyll of man, was prophecy brought at anytime, but the holy men of God spake, inspyred with the holy Ghost. The steppes of men are slypper, theyr coniectures darke, theyr opinion variable, and theyr iudgements bounded within lymittes: Iamb. de mist. aegpi. Iamblicus in his Treatise, of the misteries of Egypt, vtterly disprooueth theyr conceytes, which would haue drawne the gyft of prophecie, eyther from the lyght of nature, or from any other foūtayne, sauing the meere grace of God, In quo omnis authoritatis praesaga vis consistit, in whome consisteth the prognosticating force of all auctoritie. So Christe gaue his Father thankes, for concealing Luke. 10. 21. from the learned, what hee had reuealed vnto babes, and againe, hee chose 1. Cor. 1. 27.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the follies of the world, to confound the practise of the curious. If prophecie be supernaturall diuinitie, then can it not be taught by rule, Sed per principia diuinitus reuelata, but by principles reuealed by God onely. Therefore, Nabuch • donozor acknowledgeth the gyft of prophecie in Daniel, Dan. 4. 23. Quia spiritus Domini in illo erat, the spirite of God was in him: and the wife of Balthasar, seeketh to withdraw her husbād, from the frutlesse cōfidence, which he reposed in the foolish prophetes: that had lost the pole, by this playne demonstration deducted. From the cause efficient, that there was in Daniell, Dan. 5. 12. Spiritus amplior & ostensio secretorum, a more plentifull and ample spirite, iogyned with discouerie of secretes. Not long before the tyme, that Saule was called and aduaunced to the gouernement, he was aduertised by Samuel the Prophetes, as it were for an ernest of Gods fauour toward him, that he should prophecie, but when? Marie 1. Reg. 10. 6. Cum insilierit in te spiritus Domini, when the spirite of God hath inuaded thee, &c. Iosias is sayde to haue beene Eccle. 4. 93. Diuinitus directus: and without him, sayth Esay, we neyther knowe where to finde, Thesauros(i) Esay. 45. 3. absconditos, vel arcana secretorum. Though Balack would giue me the house full of golde or siluer, sayth the prophete Balam, I can neyther Num. 22. 18 choppe nor chaunge the word of God, to speake more or lesse: and againe, Num. 22. 38 Nunquid potero loqui, &c? Can I speake or delyuer any other thing, then that which God hath put into my mouth, &c. Putas quoties fata aperienda sunt, Ioseph. Antiquit. lib. 4 cap. 6. in nobis fitum esse, &c. Thinke you sayth another Prophete in Iosephus, that so often as the destinies are to be reuealed, it consifteth in our wyll and power, to suppresse or vtter what we lyst? Not so, Nam ipse spiritus oracula quae vult, profert nobis,
nec scientibus nec cogitantibus, For the spirite himselfe giueth out, what Oracles it pleaseth him, when wee doo neyther vnderstand nor thinke of it. Cassandra, telleth in lyke manner, that when the spirite entereth into her minde, Eurip. in Iphig.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , it causeth those, that are estraunged from themselues, as it were by a kinde of traunce to prophecie. Psal. 84. 4. Audiam quid loquatur in me Dominus, I wyll heare what God speaketh in mee, (sayth the Prophete Dauid) and so might he be bolde to doo, since Gods spirite spake bothe by his voice and penne: 2. Reg. 2. 23. Spiritus Domini loquutus est per me, & sermo eius per linguam meam, and againe, Psal. 44. 2. Lingua mea calamus, velociter scribentis, My tongue is lyke the penne of a swift writer, &c. Bothe Manue and Iudg. 13. 22. his wife, were made acquainted with the secrete purpose of almightie GOD: but, from his owne mouth, and by the seruice of an Angell. Eliseus discouered the 4. Reg. 5. 26 inward thoughts of Gieze, and all the words which the King spake in his priuie 4. Reg. 6. 12. chamber: but by the grace of Amos, 3. 7. dispensation, and therefore we maye note a great regard in Hely, to distinguishe betweene reuelation and phantasie, when hee gaue aduise to Samuel (declaring what had chaunced him, before he were instructed in the word of God) to returne to 1. Reg. 3. 9. sleepe and not aunswere any more, tyll the voice had called him againe, supposing that a dreame would vanish, lyke a shaddowe of it selfe: but the voice of God would not giue ouer, tyll his holy wyll and pleasure were accomplished, Sap. 7. 9. Sensum tuum quis sciet nisi dederis sapientiam & miseris spiritum in sanctum tuum de altissimis. Who shall attaine to thy sence, vnlesse thou giue wisedome, and sende downe the spirite from the highest. He giueth Acts. 17. 26. Inspirationem & omnia: and the Preacher earnestly perswadeth vs, in no wise to set our hearts vpon a vision or prophecie, vnlesse it descend Eccle. 49. 3. Ab altissimo: the reason followes in saint Paule, 1. Cor. 2. 11. Quae Dei sunt, nemo nouit nisi spiritus Dei, For these thinges that a • e of GOD, or belong to him, are not otherwise to be vnderstoode then by his spirite.

This warrant of Gods spirite, therefore is the cheefest and surest meane of distinguishing, betweene the false and true but yet since that olde mounte-bancke of 3. Reg. 13. 8. Bethel, was not ashamed to pretende this warrant, when he went about to cousin & deceiue. Ioh. 3. 8. and the false Prophetes in the dayes of Ieremy, demaunded how the spirite of God could for sake them, &c. We must examine them by the word of God, as by the touch of truth: for if an Angel should preach any other faith or doctrine, then that which beganne first at Acts. 1. 8. Ierusalem, and hath been since dispearsed ouer all the world, let him be Gala. 1. 8. Anathema, God is offended heauily with a mortall sinner, which abuseth his holy name, much more with a deceytfull Prophete, that dare carpe at his prerogatiue, and therefore let them vaunt of Ierusalem, the Arke, the Cherubin,
the couenant, or of what they lyst, a protestation which is • latly repugnant to the deede or acte it selfe, auayleth not to strike of the fine or amercement, which is set vppon those malepart aspyring iackes, that couer lyes with hope, and hookes with honny. The reason why saynt Peter would not forsake, or leaue his maister for all the world, was because he had the Iohn. 6. 68. wordes of euerlasting lyfe, which are a lanterne to our steppes, a fountayne of true wisedome, a staffe of stedfast comfort, and an Oracle of certayntie.

The noble men of Thessalonica, for tryall of the soundnesse of that spyrite, wherewith the Disciples and Apostles taught, repayred to the text of holy writte, Acts. 17. 11. Scrutantes scripturas, an hae ita se haberent, &c. Searching and examining the Seriptures, whether these thinges were indeede as they were tolde. And to this Oracle our Sauiour, Iohn. 5 39. sent the Scribes and Phariseis, who seemed to make doubt of his aucthoritie: For these are in deede, Hebr. 3. 12. Discretores spirituum & intentionum cordis, Iohn. 11. 48. The discerners of our spirites, and of the purpose of our hart. According to the Scriptures ryghtly vnderstoode, not onelye scruples were Deut. 17, 10. decided, whyle the lawe bare all the stroke, but cases of our soules, shall be Iohn. 12. 48. determyned in the daye of iudgement. Shall the people, sayth Esay, require a vision of theyr God, for the lyuing from the dead? Ad Esai. 8. 20. legem magis & testimonium, quod •• non dixerint iuxta verbum, hoc non erit eis matutina lux, Rather let them come to the lawe and the testimony: but if they speake not according to this worde, they shall not enjoye the morning lyght, &c. And therefore, as we blame not Saule, for asking 1. Reg 28. 6. counsayle of the Priestes and Prophets, to whom the gyft of soūd interpretatiō, was allotted and Deut. 17. 9. Mala. 2. 7. assigned by the mercie of almightie God, that the people might haue euer an assured ground whereon to rest: and the 1. Cor, 14. 32 spirits of the Prophets, might be subiect to the same. So God hath rased him out of the booke of lyfe, for seeking 1. Re. 28, 16. knowledge by the wicked spyrites, when the spyrite of his God had quite forsaken him. The prophet Dauid would not be beleeued any further, touching the plot of that holy Temple, which his sonne should builde, then he could bring proofe, 1. Par. 28, 19. Omnia venisse scripta manu Domini ad se, vt intelligeret vuiuersa opera exemplaris, that all thinges appertayning to the same, came to him written with the hand of God, that hee might vnderstand all the workes, of the patterne, Christe by the warrant of the word, approoued himselfe to haue been that very right and true Messias: whome bothe Abraham beheld in spyrite, with exceeding Iohn. 8▪ 56. ioy, and Dauid with great Psal. 109. 1. Matt. 24, 22. satisfaction, and 2. Cor. 3, 15. Moses preached dayly in his ceremonies, wherevppon S. Paule dooth iustifie the doctrine, taught by the Disciples & Apostles, cheefely for this cause, that it was the Acts. 26. same which the Prophets had foretold, and Moses had prefigured, Moysen habent & prophetas, for they haue
Moses and the Prophets, said Abrahā to the glutton, that was plaged & tormēted in the gulfe of hell, to whome if they wyl giue no credit, neither wil they to a mā that should arise from the Luke. 16. 21. dead, &c. There may be, & I dout not but there are at this day, Sedechiasis great store, which deliuer rules by rote, and crie out, Viuit Dominus, haec dicit Dominus, cum Iere. 14. 14. Dominus non sit loquutus, thus sayth our Lord, when he spake it not. There may be forged visions, and reuelations, but they carrie no •
Mich. 3. 6, 7. Responsa Domini, the resolutions of God. The world maye runne of wheeles, but they are not those, of which Ezechiel the Prophet spake, In quibus Ezec. 20. erat vitae spiritus: there may be strong and mighty blastes • o shake the rockes, and turne vp mountavnes from the bottome, but not in the 3. Re. 13. 12. spirite of the God almighty. Diuerse maye chatte and bable, Fabulationes, olde wiues tales, Psal. 119. 86. Sed non vt lex tua, but they are not lyke vnto thy lawe. Wherefore we maye finde plainly by Iosephus, that albeit the plagues, and myseries of the stubborne and styfnecked lewes, were reuealed beforehande to theyr generall: yet so great care was taken in that wretched time, that the people might not be abused, or misledde by priuate fancies: wanting warrant, in the written wordes, that the story setteth downe withall, Ioseph. de bell. Iudg. lib. 3. chp. 14 Probe nouisse illum prophetarum libros, that hee was verie skilfull, or well learned in the bookes of the Prophetes. Dionisius Dion. de Bap. vt citat. ab Eusebio. a godly Bishoppe, beeing warned in a vision not to bee too scrupulous, in forbearing to reade bookes of heretiques: considering hee myght as easilie finde matters there, wherby to confute themselues, as saint Paule dyd in Epimenides, Aratus, Menander, and which is more in the verye marble stones, to garnishe and set foorth the spowse of Christe: would not giue credite to the same, as comming from the spirite of God, although hee were bothe learned and able to discerne, before hee had examined and prooued it, Voci Apostolicae conuenientem, to be agreeable to the voice Apostolique, alluding eyther to that warrant, of making 1. Thes. 5, 21 proofe of all things, so that we retayne no more then is religious and good: or to another place where all things are sayd, to be Titus. 1. 15. Munda mundis, that is, cleane to those that are cleane, or to the Acts. 10. 15. sheete, let downe to Peter by fowre corners, shewing that nothing may be counted common or vncleane, which God hath purified. We know that no man can lay any other 1. Cor. 3, 11. foundation, then that which is already layd for vs, which is Iesus Christ, that we are built vpon the Ephe. 2. 20. Prophetes and Apostles, Christ being the corner stone, & that all knowledge, which hath no ground in him nor in his word: not onely puffeth vp, as S. Paule 1. Cor. 8. 1. declares, but banisheth for euer, frō the sight of him, who chose the meanes, which were accounted foolish in this world, & to the sight of flesh and bloud, to confound the wicked, in the pride of theyr presuming pollicie.
Whosoeuer therefore Num. 12. 2 murmureth, with Mary against Moses, picketh quarrels Num. 16. 3 with Dathan and Abiron, against those that are in office, to correct and punish sinne, setteth vppe one alter against another, Praeuaricationis animo mistrusteth God with Israell in the deserte, maketh a hotch 4, Reg. 4. 1. potch or a mingle mangle, betweene the lawfull and true(r) Iosu. 22. 22. seruice of God, and the blasphemies of Idoles, with the priestes of Samaria, or demaundeth counsaile and aduise of Belzebub, the God of Accaron(s) Exo. 14. 12 with Ochozias, can neither be thought to be inspired by the gyft of God, esteemedas a christiā, regarded as an honest man, nor admired and(t) Exo. 14. 11 frequēted as a prophet. Wherfore, first wee must away with wicked Ada mites, whose manner was, so often as they burned in vnlawfull or vncleane desire, to cry Spiritus in hanc concaluit, my spyrite waxeth whot, or is inflamed to thys woman, though she were the wyfe of an other,(x) Aen. Silu. hist. Bohem. pag. 109. and therevppon to enioy and vse her, as it were by warrant from the court of heauen, so farre as the pastor was enforced, to confirme, to seale and ratifie, the bargaine made betweene the parties, by that text in Genesis, though wrested like the deuils Scriptum est, Gen. 1. 22. Encrease & multiply,(y) Mat. 4. 4. 10 next a way with the most irregular, and lawfull Annabaptists, who neuer vouched other reason, for cōmitting murder, whoredome, theft, and whatsoeuer sinne they were inclined most vnto, then the stirring & suggesting of theyr owne dishonest spirite: when the moode enflamed(&) Steidan. in hist. them, and last of all, away with all the fayned reuelations, and visions of Roger Bacon, frier Hilton, Sauanorola, with the rest of that vngodly crewe: because they dare not shewe theyr faces against the churche of Christ, which is Acies ordinata, an armie marshalled in order.

Whatsoeuer credite they haue gotten (as Tertullian writes) in Castris rebellium, vbi esse tantum promereri est, in the campe of rebles, where a man which being and assisting onely, may come forwarde and atchiue great honour, yet they drawe no charter frō the written worde, theyr gesses are not warraunted by the holye ghoste, they wrest but prooue not, they deceiue but teach not, and limme theyr letters ratherTertul. de praescript haeret. with the watrish colours of abuse, then with the lasting oyles, of plainenesse and religious simplicity. I know that straunge forwarnings haue beene fathered vppon S. Bridgette, Abbot Ioachim and others of the better sorte, expressing with most bright and liuely coloures, the debate and discorde which hath beene passing whotte, in this vnhappye age of ours, betweene Iacob and Esau, and no furder off, thou in the bow els of Rebecca, but since we finde that Psal. 84. 6. Dominus narrabit in scripturis populorum &c. God will declare in the scriptures of his people, that trueth ought to be resounded from the toppes Luk. 12. 3. of houses: and that such toyes as these, which neyther were prefigured by Moses & the Prophets, nor are now comprised in the gospel, nor approued by the church of Christ, deserue to be marshalled among those fancies and Apocrifas,
which Hieron. ad Eustoc. Eustochium was taught to shunne, as the serpents egges, then regarded for theyr weyght, I thinke it safer to conceale thē with a vaile of silence, then by example to let in a worlde of blasphemies. For otherwise this incōuenience must needs fall out, that as nothing is so foolishe or ridiculous, but hath beene pleaded & defended by some one Philosopher or other, so nothing is so godlesse and erronious, which may not be coloured with the varnishe of dissimulation. If now it be demaunded who shall expounde, interprete or apply the scriptures: for the siftinge of the spirites and theyr prophecies, in this case I aunswer, that none are so fitte, as the lawfull pastours of the Church: for that was the plaine meaning of saint Paule, when he resolued that the spirites of the Prophets, shoulde be 1. Cor. 14. 33. subiect to the Prophets, because our sauiour was no God of discorde and dissention, but of peace and vnity.

Prouided alwayes, that these pastors be called orderly, as Heb. 5. 4. Aron was, that they be not greased in the Iud. 17. 12 hande as the Leuit of Michas, that they enter by the doore Ioh. 10. 13. and climbe not vppe another way, like a theefe and a robber: that they be as Apollo was, Act. 18. 24 Potentes in scripturis, mighty in the scriptures, able to exhorte Tit. 1. 9. in sounde doctrine, and to conuince those that oppose theyr mallice against trueth: if otherwise, I may be bolde to saye with Martian the learned father, that it, had beene better for the bishops, to haue thrust their hand into a bush of thornes, Soc. hist. lib. 5. cap 20. then to haue layde them on the heads of such vnlearned ministers, as haue neyther skill to teache the simple, to restor the weake, nor to reduce the wandring. For if it were affirmed of the Iewish prieste, who was but a figure Heb. 5. 1. of that priest, by whom ours are authorised in the minestery of the trueth, that his lippes Mala. 2, 7. shoulde keepe the lawe, and that we should require it at his handes, because he was a messenger of the God of hostes, if he were then made Deu. 17. 10. iudge of plea and plea, and enfeoffed with so sure a promise as De doctr. Christi. lib. 4. cap. 27. S. Augustine doth plainely teache, that though he liued ill, yet he coulde not teach amisse. Howe much rather may we warraunt and assure our selues, that lawfull pastors 1. Tim. 4. 14 2. Tim. 1. 6. orderly succeding, in the ordinary function of the twelue Apostles, which were prefigured by the twelue tribes of Israel: to whom the sonne of God hath promised his grace and diuine assistaunce, so ofte as two Mat. 18. 2. or three be gathered together in his name, wyth whom at his departure hence, he left not onely Ioh. 20. 23. 1. Cor. 5. 5. keyes of discipline, but the myghty woorking of hys holy spyrite, with these heauenly propertyes to Rom. 16. 15. sanctify, to suggest Ioh. 14. 25 vnto theyr mindes, and memories from time to time, what soeuer had beene eyther sayd or doone by him, to leade Ioh. 16. 13. them into all trueth, and remaine with them to the consumation of the worlde: and not with them alone, but with as many as(x) Mat. 28. 20. shoulde Ioh. 17. 20. be inserted, and engrassed on the stocke of fayth, by the mynistery of theyr preaching, how much rather may we warraunt, and
assure our selues I say, that these shall alwayes holde the skill of measuring, and peising doubts the depth of vnderstanding, and the meanes to make an ende of them.

These graces are as ringes, or pawnes and pledges of goodwyll, betweene the church and Christ her spouse, not for one day but for all dayes, they can not corrupt and putrifie like puddles in the filthy cesterns of abuse: but renewe from time to time, and spring vppe to life euerlasting. The church of Christ shall neuer want true pastors to direct vs in to a godly course, although Miltiades obserued rightly, that vppon the death of Maximilla the wise woman, otherwise called the false prophetesse:Euse. lib. 5. cap. 16. not one prophet could be found nor heard of, for the space of fourteene yeeres together, among her foolish sectaries. For, as that graue and learned Doctor Gamaliel sayd in the counsaile openly, if the workeAct. 5. 38. be of men it may be dissolued, but if it be of God it is indissoluble.

THus farre we finde, that reuelation and warraunt by the worde of God, are notes whereby we may discerne, but yet because experiēce hath taught vs, that the false Prophet in Bethel, was not ashamed to pretende, that the worde of God, had beene reuealed to him, by an angell, which was false, & sathan likewise, to put in claime to the second note, by2 Re. 13, 18. M •• 4. 9. vouching text against the trueth it selfe. We must not altogether stande vppon pretended colours, or vaine flourishies vppon the text: but trye them in an other poynt more effectuall then eyther of both those, name ly whither they professe a resolut, and cōstant fayth, in the bloud & merites of our Lord & only sauior Christ Iesus, for no man (saith S. Iohn) can doo the workes of God, without beleefe in him whom he hath sent.Ioh. 5. 29. Againe fayth is the perfect obiect, whych the lookes of God regarde, and therefore, whatsoeuer fable, fancie, figure or conceite springes not from thys sweete roote, is damnable.

The gift of miracles, was not common at the first beginning of theIer. 5 3. Church: to all that bare the name of Christe, by title rather then by troth, but to those onely that beleeued in his death, and such a drugge true fayth is holden by the holy ghoste, and of so rare account, as no greater weight hereof thē one sily graine of musterd seede, is able to remooue a mountaine. Wherefore S. Paule repayred neyther to the pole, the Planettes, fixed starres, nor salt Sea Gods, vppon▪ the wracke: but toMat. 17. 19 thys certaine meane, affirming with a stedfast and inuincible beleefe, that all thinges shoulde succeede and take effect in order, as they hadAct. 27, 14. beene reuealed in the vision. Fayth is the salt, which ought to season all our thoughts and deedes: it is the wedding garment, without which we can not enter to the feaste, and the marke which sequestrith the goates from the Lambes, and the chosen from the castawayes. By fayth not onelyHeb. 11. 33. Sampson, Barac, Dauid and the rest preuailed against mighty states,
but simple personnes, babes and women against Sathan and his ministers. If a prophet, which expoundeth dreames or geueth warning, of a thinge which after comes to passe: endeuour to withdrawe the people from the seruice of theyr God, wherin defecte of fayth and true beleefe is signified. Non audies verba prophetae illius, thou shalt not heereDeu. 13. 12 (sayth God himselfe) the words of that Prophet. For euery spyrite that confesseth Iesus Christe, to haue come in the fleshe is of God, and and euery spirite that dissolueth Iesus, is of Antechrist. The wicked Arrians1. Ioh. 4. 3. therefore, who tookevppon them to deuine, what foule weather shoulde betide the church, were not capable of this gift: because they swarued from the sounde beleefe concerning Consubstantialitye, no more was Simon Magus, Theudas, Marcus the Magician, nor in our time the Anabaptists and Familistes of loue: howsoeuer some of them haue hunted most ambitiously, & eagerly to be reputed skilful in those matters.

Beside this principle is so certainely and infalibly true, as no HereAug. de. curio. quest. epist. 5, 6. ticke in these dayes (sayth S. Augustine) dares offer himselfe to the combat: Nisi nomine copertus Christiano, without being couered, at the leaste with the name or title of a Christian, and again Omnes Christum praedicant, sed qua fide et ore, ipsi rationem sunt reddituri: al preach Christ, but with what fayth or countenaunce, they shall one day giue accountDe Trin. li. 5 Lact. de. vera relig. Euse. orat. ad santos. cap. 18. Con. louin. lib. 1. &c. He that is not with vs is against vs, and whosoeuer cleaueth not to Nazareth, must filch his prophecies from Iericho. Against thys principle, it may be that the rare example of the Sibilles, will be pressed and obiected by some busie bodies, which had rather cauill then conforme themselues to trueth, and with better collour by so much as Lactantius, Constantine, S. Ierome, Eusebius with some others haue affoorded them, the gyft of prophecy &c. For answer and dispatch wereof, I woulde be very loth to diminish, or detract from theyr discreete & bash full virgins: the least part of praise or commendation, which hath been assigned, and allotted to them by the learned. But when I call to minde howe seldome one kinde of instaunce hath beene founde, against that grounde of S. Paule, Fides per auditum, fayth comes by hearing, hearingRom. 10. 17 by the worde of God &c.

It seemeth very straunge, that they which neuer heard the preacher, nor examined the word, shoulde not slightly touch, but plainely specify the misteries of our saluation. Againe, it is most euident by Liuy, and by other writers and reporters of the state of Rome, that duumuiri sacrorum, which hauing charge to looke into the prophecies, were first sworn to report no more then trueth, brought out such warninges of erecting aulters to false Gods, repayring idoles, yeelding sacrafice, with other execrable monuments of Atheisme and grosse idolatrie, as no wise man will iudge, coulde yssewe from a person, or from diuers persons that
were eyther guided, or inspired with diuine intelligence. For as lawfully in all respects might the priestes of Samaria, Deum colere, diis quoque suis seruire, iuxta consuetudinem gentium, de quibus translati fuerant,4. Re. 17. 33 both worshippe the true God, and yet serue theyr false and feyned goddes, according to the manner of the nations, from which they wereMat. 6. 24 transported to Samaria, as well may we serue God and Mammon, and speake halfe Hebrewe and halfe Ashdod, as blende the graces of the spirite, and the doctrine of Idolaters in one mash together. But since I find a sorte of godly verses, vouched out of theyr vessels, by the learned fathers of the church, which could not flowe from any wicked or vngodly sincke, I will forbeare to iudge, or to except against the iudgement of antiquity, which hath waded in the cause before my time, supposing for an aunswer to the doubts and scruples which I put, that eyther the same maiestrates of Rome, which caused the bookes that were founde in the monument of Numa Pompilius, to be wasted in a burning flame: because, they specified a certaine forme of religion and doctrine, greatly differing from that, which at the time of finding was in vse & exercise at Rome, inuented likewise sundry foyles and shaddowes of Idolatry, to make the directories sutable with the present state, or that they deuil cast these darke and mistie vapores, to obscure the light ratherthen condemne the women, whom diuerse doo beleeue, and I dare not deny to haue been inspyred, wyth this gift aboue their equalles. But though we should admitte them for theyr priuiledge into the formost rancke, what forceth this against my grounde: for howsoeuer God himselfe Qui vniuersa operatus est perse impiū quoque ad diē malū, who hath wrought all thinges, euen the wicked to theyr heauy day, except againstPro. 16. 4. the rule, or for the glory of his name extort the trueth out of their lips with hate and prosecute it to the death: this proueth not that we may dubbe or ordeine prophets when we list, of whatsoeuer sect, or limitte rules which haue a generall extent, by presidents of perticuler consideration. The purposes of God are onely known and vnderstoode by him and therefore we must keepe the beaten cawsey, without tourning to one side or other.

It is most certaine that Pharao, Abimelech, Nabuchodonosor, Baltasar, Herod, Sapores, Constans, Iulian, Valens, and the rest, had sometimes visions of terror and discouragement, sometime of grace & mercye to reclaime them frō their crooked wayes: but these can not avow these hell-houndes to be Prophets. It is well knowne that Socrates who spake and wrote so sweetely and diuinely, as Erasmus was about sometime to crye, Sancte Socrates ora pro me, was dayly wayted and attended on by a certaine spirite, which gaue warning of the priuie snares,N •
• . 22. 4. that were sette to catch and to entangle him. Balac, the wicked king of of Moab was able to foretel: that the children of Israell should deuoure
his subiects, Sicut bossolet herbas carpere, as an Oxe is wont to snatch vppe grasse, and Baalam being called foorth by the king of Moab onely to this ende, that he should accurse the saints of God, was so prompted and enstructed by the way, as he acknowliged theyr piety and godlinesse, wished that his life might ende, after the manner of those iusteNu. 23. 24. men, adding further that Israell shoulde be raysed vppe, and encouraged like a Lyon, and neuer abandon or forsake the chase, tyll they were glutted with the bloude and flaughter of theyr ennemies. If these examples be not thought sufficient to serue the tourne, whych no wise man wyll think, what can they say to Baalams asse, who plaid his part as throughly, in reproouing his maisters rash & vnaduised heate as any one, & yet I thinke it be as like, that God may extraordinarily worke in a man that wanteth fayth, as is in a beaste that is voide of reason. The Oxe kneweEsay. 1. 5. his owner, and the simple asse his maisters cribbe: but Israell knew not me, sayth the Lorde by the Prophet. The godlesse Madianites were inspiredIud. 7. 13. in a dreame, wyth the foresight of theyr owne mishap: & which may seeme moore straunge, though God alone illuminate our mindes as we learne by Daniell, yet theyr owne freendes in that verye instant, gaue a right and sounde interpretation.

The sorcerers and coniurers, which were in greatest credite with the wicked kinges: sometimes acknowledge gods holy finger, to haue wrought with Moses and the rest, as we haue heard before, sometymes confessed themselues, to be ouer▪ matched with a stronger arme, and yet they carry not the names of Prophets. Note further that the bloudy1. Re. 19. 20. messengers, which were sent foorth by Saule to apprehend Dauid, were esprised on a suddayne with the spirits of the Prophets whō they mette, and began foorthwith to prophecy. And Saule himselfe, hauing the true1. Re. 19. 24 seruaunts of God in chase, was gladde to strippe himselfe and prophecie among the rest. Wherevppon the prouerbe grewe, Nunquid et Saule1. Re. 26. 27. inter prophetas, I coulde adioyne his last wordes touching Dauid: and not longe before his ende, Faciens faciet, et potens poterit, according toIoh. 3. 30. the sentence gyuen by S. Iohn Baptist of his Maister, to the Scribes and Pharises, Hunc opertet crescere, vos autē minui, this man must enrease, but you shall be taken downe, which differ little from the first in quality Pilates wife was neither saint, nor (for any thinge I finde) of sounde beleefe,Mat. 27. 19 and yet she forbadde her husbande, as he sat in iudgement vppon the sight of a fearefull dreame, in no wise to embrewe his handes wyth the giltlesse bloude of our redeemer. With these it shall not be amisse to couple Caiphas in one lincke, who notwithstanding hee were a rancker and more professed ennemie to trueth, then any of the rest, yet in respect he was Illius anni Pontifex, the bishop or high priest for that yere, is affirmed by S. Iohn to prophecy, or if they tie thys priuiledge, rather to the chayre then to the personne, what can they pretende against theIoh. 18. 4.
straung example of the Iewes, who gathered vpō these words of Christe (where I am you can not come) a certaine glimse or priuie light, of hysIoh. 7. 35. departure to the Gentiles.

Vespasian without any kinde of charme, restored a blinde man toSueton. in Vespasi. sight, if Suetonius may be beleeued. Theorecnus erected an idole, Ioui 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and wrought straunge thinges by Magicke. The Nouatian heretickes (as Theodoret reportes) were not altogether voyde of the gyft of miracles, no more was Iudas (as S. Ambrose writes) while he remaynedEuseb. lib. 9. cap. 2. in the felowshippe. For diuers cast out deuils in the name of Christ whom notwithstanding in the latter day, he will not acknowledge for his lawfull ministers. Wherefore as the sunne shineth equally both vpponMat. 7. 22. Mat. 5. 45 the good and badde, so God imparteth gifts of nature equally to both, not as the signes of fauour to the wicked: but rather for a stronger charge vppon them, in respect of theyr vnthankfulnesse. I speake notAct. 17. 27. of him that built his aultar 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to the vnknowen God, nor of another prophet who was takē vp in Thrace, during the raigne of Constantine the seconde, with this inscription vppon his monument, Christus nascetur ex virgine et credo in eum, Christ shall be borne of a virgine, and I beleeue in him, and on the backe side was engrauen to aunswer, that Sub Irene et constantino me rursum videbit Sol, vnder the raigne of Irene and Constantine the sunne shall fee me againe, whichZonar. An. tom. 3, fell out accordingly, but I wyll cōclude this matter, wyth the true conceyte of Sozomen, that nothing fell out righter, for the certainty and euidence of trueth, then that it pleased God to quicken and inspyre the myndes, not of hys seruaunts onely, but of aliens and straungers also with hys holy gyfts, not much vnlike a skilfull and expert Musitian.Sozom. lib. 1. cap, who deuiseth extraordinary strings, for the the playing of straung musique. For no man wyl suppose that eyther Socrates, or his 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Balac, Balaam, Baalams asse, the catch-poles of king Saule, or Saule himselfe. The Madianites, an Oxe, an asse, Iudas, Caiphas, the wife of Pilate, Valens, Herode, Iulian, with all the kennell of those hell-houndes, were such prophets, as Esay, Ieremy, Ezechiell, or such as godly persons ought to reuerence, although it pleased God sometime when sinners eyther wandered, or wept by the streames of Babilon, and hunge theyr harpes vppon the braunches of the Willowes, for the taking downe of presumptions crest, or trailing of the paynted plumes of glorye in the dust, or for a manifest and certaine proofe &c. that grace is neyther, in the wyller nor in the runner: but in him that showeth mercy, or for some other secrete cause, reserued onely to the knowledge of hymselfe to worke as mightily by euery one of these and in as straung a manner as by the Sibilles or other Oracles. But cheefely let vs marke that place of S. Luke, where the wicked spirites which tooke knowledge, both of Christ and Paule, because they kept and helde one certaine course, refused afterwarde to stoope, or yeelde one iote to the Acts. 19. 13. 14, 15. sonnes of Sceua
the Iewishe priest, adiuring them in the name of Christe, because theyr fayth was false and counterfeyte.

Furthermore, because many which professe Christe outwardlye, denie him in theyr hearts according to the sentence of the Prophete, Esai. 29. 13. Matth. 15, 8. Populus hic labiis me honorat, cor autem eius longe est a me, and as our owne experience hath dayly prooued by the death of many, which although they lyue together with vs, in the bosome of our outwarde church, are notwithstanding made away: for witchcrafte, sorcerye, and such lyke trumperies, by iustice of the lande, I ioygne to these another note, which is, that whosoeuer wyll auerre, and iustifie the course of his proceeding: eyther touching myracles, or prophecie, to be consonaunt to trueth, must only worke by Iesus Christ and in his holy name, without eyther sawce of Magicke, helpe of spyrite, or any mixture of impertynent, and most vnprofitable ceremonies. For, euen as Christe himselfe beeing planted and enstalled at the right hand of his Father, hath Ephe. 1. 21. subdued all things vnder his owne feete, so certaynlie there is none other name vnder heauen, whereby Esai, 45. 23. Rom. 14, 11. we may be saued: nor, whereat the knees Philip. 2, 10. of all thinges shall bowe, neyther is it possible for any man, to speake with the spirite of God, that sayth 1. Cor, 12. 3. Anathema to Iesus. The poore widdowe in Sareptha, forbare to acknowledge Elias to be the man of God: tyll shee had heard 3. Reg. 17. 21 the manner of his inuocation, touching her sonnes recouerie. Samuel reuealed vnto Saule, the deepest secretes of his heart, but not before the page were gone away, that he might declare vnto him, in lyke manner the 1. Reg. 2, 27. woord of God. The people would not permitte that Ionathas, should leese one heaire, 1. Re. 14 45 Quod cum Domino operatus esset: because hee wrought with God, &c. The voice of Esaye, Ieremy, Ezechiell, is alwayes, Haec dicit Dominus: of Micheas, Mcih. 4, 5. Nos ambulauimus in nomine Domini nostri, we haue walked in the name of our Lord: of Agabus, Haec dicit Acts. 21. 11. spiritus sanctus, these thinges sayth the holy Ghost, &c. Christe cast out spirites, Verbo Matth. 8. 16. with a word, that is, by adiuring them, not by Belzebub the prince of the deuilles, but in his owne aucthoritie: and againe, Matt. 12. 28. Spiritu Dei, in Gods spirite. Peter had none other charme, then these playne and pithy words, Sanet te Acts 9. 34. Dominus Iesus, our Lord Iesus Christe restore thee: nor Paule, for the recouerie of Publius his Father, then the Acts. 28▪ 6. laying on of his most blessed handes with inuocation. The seely captiue woman, in her cure of the King of Iberes chylde, vsed these wordes onely, Socr. lib. 1. cap. 16. Christus qui multos seruauit, &c. Christe who hath preserued many, shall lykewise restore this infant. The diet which the Prophet Elizeus, prescribed vnto Naaman for preseruation of his health: was onely to serue God, and what the meanes of curing in those dayes were thought to be, appeareth by that Naaman, onely looked that Elizeus should first call 4. Reg. 5, 11. vppon the name of 〈1 page missing〉
cumstaunce of swelling, is not verbally expressed in the text: but since the fleshe of Christe was passible by nature, and subiect to the paynesEsay. 53, 7. and agonies of death by wyll, I finde no reason, but his body might as well, swell as bleede, especially considering the same Prophete, vttereth that we were healed with his blacke and blewe, which colour sildomeEsay. 53, 5. commeth, without swelling in the place affected. We know, that Christ was perfect man in euery poynt, excepting onely sinne, and therefore men had neede he warie, that they scant not any parcell of his suflering, least they take as much from his merite, Quanto enim plura, pro meIn Psal. 32. Christus passus est, tanto plus illi debeo: for the more that Christe hath suffered for mee (sayth saint Augustine) the more am I indebted to his mercie.

Thus much for the matter of the charme, as for the manner it is altogether chyldishe and ridiculous, and so much the worse to bee lyked▪ as it runnes in ryme, according to the course of Apollos olde weather beaten Oracles. Besyde, whereas the iudgement of this cause requyreth, Sensus exercitatos ad discretionem boni & mali,Hebr. 5. 14. sences well practised, to discerne betweene good and euyll, the woman is so fonde and simple as shee speaketh, onely lyke a parrette, and is not able to delyuer any reason of her dealing. One of the reysters which serued vnder the Frenche Admirall, at the siege of Poictiers, was founde after hee was dead, to haue about his necke a pursse of Taffata, and within the same a peece of parchment, full of charecters in Hebrew: beside many cyrcles, semicircles, tryangles, &c. with sundrieHistor. des troubles. Liu. 8. shorte cuttes, and shreddings of the Psalmes, Deus misereatur nostri, &c Angelis suis mādauit de te, &c. Super aspidem & Basiliscū, &c. As if the Prophecies which properly belong to Christe, might be wrested to the safegard & defēce of euery priuate mā or men could draw defensatiues, out of the drugges of that obscure philosophy, wherewith Cornelius Agrippa, slubbered so many sheetes of paper to so lyttle purpose. But some saye, that the wordes which our women vse, are not offensiue: no more are the names of Adonaei, Iehoua, tetragrammaton, as the learned vse them: but, as they are abused and corrupted by the coniurers. Neyther are the Samaritanes reprooued, for the worship which they dyd to GOD: but for that they matched it with honour of the fayned gods,4. Reg. 11. 33 which were adored by the Gentyles. Saynt Iohn ranne not out of the baines, because they were a meane of strength, & comfort to the body: but because Cerinthus the peeuish heretique, gaue him cause to feare, that the roofe would come downe ouer him. Clictouius, one of theScepper. li. 3 cheefe diuines of Paris, in his tyme, mislyked not a certayne booke, presented to him by a freend of his, because it conreyned many godlye prayers vnto God, but forsomuch as they were enterlarded, with a mixtureDan. 2 23. of arte Magicall. The head of Danielles image was of beaten gold,
but the feete of yron. The wine which goeth downe the throte lyke honny, byteth at the last lyke an Adder. The cuppe was glorious, wherinApo. 17. 4. the strumpette dronke of all abbomination: Vicina sunt vitia virtutibus, and vices border vppon vertues (sayth S. Ierome) as superstitionIero. con. lucifer. vppon religion, prodigality vppon bounty, but vnder the greene grasse, sleepeth a serpent. The deuill can trans-fourme himselfe into an angell, and it is no deinty with him to conceale his ougly feete, wyth the long robe of a Pharesie. If theyr meaning were but halfe so plaine as they pretende, why cleaue they more to ceremony then to substaunce, Cur verborum aucupia, et litterarum tendiculas consectantur, why hunte they thus eagerly, for the snares of words and the sprindges of letters? why preferre they certaine prescirpt fourmes, deuised by themselues, before the course which was commended vnto vs by Christ, and obserued by his Apostles? what ayleth thē that they can not sound distincktHieron. ad D • am lye Shiboleth, or as S. Ierome writeth, of the Munckes of Palestine, what letteth them to vtter theyr owne meaning in our language. Such curiosity and streigning of courtesey about slight trifles: emplies no simple, or plaine fayth in theyr exercise. No man drinketh, both sweete and bitter water out of one fountaine, no braunch beareth both grapes & thistles, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 & let no mā (saithIgnat. ad Mariam. Ignatius) be coūted godly, that entermixeth any thing that is euil with that which is good &c. the reason is, because a little leauen corrupteth al the past, one graine of Assa foetida marreth a persume, and halfe of oneGal. 5. 9. dramme of Acconitum, is able to infect and taint a boxe full of restoratiues.

Chrisostome putting the case as fauourably for these charmers as he can deuise, concludeth with a perēptory censure, vpon all their sleightsChrist. in col. 3. ho. 8 and trickes of of legier du maine: Etenim supertitiosa illa quae aegrotis applicantur, etiam si mille modis philosophentur, qui exillis quaestum faciunt, dicentes Deum inuocamus, et praeterea nihil facimus, et quicquid eiusmodi praetendunt, vt christiana est anus et fidelis &c Idolo latriam tamen sapiunt, for all these superstitious toyes, which are applyed to the ficke, vnder coloure and pretence of cure, howsoeuer it lykes those that rayse a profite by the same, to discourse and flourishe like Philosophers. A thousande wayes, saying we doo onely call vppon the name of God, and doo nothing els, or how soeuer they pretende, that the olde woman which applyes the same, is a Christian, faythfull, and a well affected woman. Yet doo they smacke and sauor of Idolatry. Non potestenim homochristianus magicis carminibus vti, sed a seruo Christi, potius anniliam debet petere, For a Christian (sayth S.Hiero. in vita. Hilla. Ierome) can not vse these charmes of Magicke, but ought rather to repayre to the seruants of Christ for remedy. We finde that Christe sayde often, Scriptum est, and so did the deuill once, wherfore in the meaning
not the letter, the person not the pretence, the substaunce not the ceremony, the finall drift not the middle streines, the lawfulnes of that which is donne, not the couetous desire, of that which some require & wish to be donne ought to be regarded. For euen as we say, that it is a matter of small weight, that the wordes themselues giue no kinde of offence &c. So may we finde that a certaine •• gistrate and hys sonne Niceas, labored S. Policarpe, to conforme himselfe, to the Princes orders,Euse. lib. 4 cap. 4. in this manner, Quid maliest dicere domine Caesar, illi sacrificare, et sic tandem euadere, what hurt is it to say, O Lord Caesar, & then to sacrifice, and so to seape without all punishment. But God who parteth or deuideth his prerogatiue, with none woulde not so much as winke at this: and therefore, the good father was content to bee racked, and tormented in a thousand sortes, rather then he wold transgreffe the least parte of his duety.

This is indeede the way, Verbis non rectis irritandi dominum, to4. Re. 17. 9 prouoke the wrath of God with wordes that are not righe, in which respect, these persons must renounce formalities, and fall to that playne course of wordes: or in that sence which was obserued in the purest times, as Sanet te dominus Iesus. And againe, in Nomine Domini Iesu, surge et ambula &c. or els this parciall adhearing to the formes of wordes and sillables, will alwayes giue a touch of the base alay, whereof the charmes and figures are compounded. But such sometime and so greate are sathans wiles, in supporting this fonde craft, which is indeede one of the strongest pillers of his seate, as fearing least it myght be some disgrace to him, that Salamon without his helpe or knowledge of his artes, shoulde winne the reputation of the wisest and discreetest man aliue, hath caused certaine of his schollers and disciples, to gyue out a foolish tale, that Salomon was author of the greatest parte of charmes, which are in practise at thys day: that at the least, one science myght be graffed on the stocke of trueth, and for the proofe hereof, they vouch the credite of losephus, whervnto I aunswer, first, that this prescript forme, seemeth to haue beene referred by theyr author, not to any flourysh or deuise of man, but to an extraordinary grace frō God himselfe, as that of Dauid, to kill Goliah wyth a sling, of Sampson to dispatch so many wyth the Iawe bone of an asse, of young Toby to restore hys fathers fight by the lyuer of a fish, of S. Peter and S. Paule to cure men with theyr shaddowes, and handkerchefes &c Which if they coulde aswell maintaine, by warraunt of the text, as they defende it, out of registers of olde wyues tales▪ I would subscribe to theyr Probatum est, according to the circumstances of the time, wherein the proofe fell out, and accept it as I doo the rest with reuerence.

Againe, vpon due tryall, and precise examination of the writers words, and cheefely by the straunge example of Eleazar (I finde) that greater
vertue was ascribed to the knowledge & right vse of the simples, which were learnedlye compounded in the cure, then to the wordes whichTob. 6. 6. were adioygned for a ceremony. Tobias was enstructed by an Angell, howe to vse the gall and lyuer of the fishe, without any prescript fourme of words. And Salomon, whome God enabled to dispute of all hearbes and plantes, from the Cedar trees in Libanus, to the Pellytorie3. Re. 4. 33. roote, that grew out of the wall: beside, De iumentis volucribus reptilibus & piscibus, Was more lyke to put in practise what hee might auowe, then to deuise newe toyes, which no skyll can iustifie. Moreouer it appeareth, that the drugges of Salomon dyd euer good: which prooues his arte, whereas the charmes, and indyrect attemptes of sorcerets with vs, abuse more often, then theyr cunning serueth them to ease, or to diminishe payne, because the cunning of the deuyll is to driue men by extremities of anguishe and distresse, eyther to dispayre or blasphemy. Iosephus addeth that these charmes (if wee maye call them so) were forcible against wicked spirites: whereas oures are for the most parte, eyther first deuised or compounded by theyr counsayle. Beside, before the bare and naked name of Salomon, maye seeme to countenaunce so vyle a misterie, we must be sure that he professed this, before his fall, and that it was rather an effect of knowledge, then a bud or braunche of incredulitie: for as I doubte not, but his Egyptian trull brought him diuerse sortes, of such lyke merchaundise out of Egypt: so this among the rest, might seeme to charge the sumpter horse. Last of all, I declared once before, and it is certaine, as the Rabbies of the Iewes themselues confesse, that many tales were foysted, into the Cabala before the tyme of Iosephus. And this not vnlyke to creepe in with the rest, considering the Scriptures, which are so precise, particular, and curious, in rypping vp as well the faultes, as follies of this King: haue not so much as glaunced at this one, although for weight it ouer-match a number: I wyll not shewe what credite, any singular example can beare against a generall precept especially, not recommended as some others are of Rahab, Phinees, &c. because I knowe not any man so simple, but is able of himselfe to satisfie this argument.

A Man would thinke, that these two latter notes, that is, professing to beleeue in Iesus Christe, and eyther diuining, or curing the diseased in his name, might teach vs to distinguishe betweene Gabriell and Lucifer, betweene Esay and Sedechias, betweene Peter and Simon Magus, betweene a message of assuraunce, and a blast of errour. But yet since Semeias the false prophete, was not ashamed to sende out his pamphlets, In Iere. 29. 25. nomine Domini, since the false prophetes, in the dayes of Micheas, vaunted that God was in the Mich. 3. 8. middest of them, since many as we reade in Zacharye, shall giue out Zach. 13. 3. lyes in the name of God, and bothe, Matt. 7. 22. Prophetare in nomine Domini, & eijcere daemonia,
both Prophecied and cast out deuilles in the name of God: whom notwithstanding he wyll not acknowledge for his owne in the latter daye. Againe, since euerie tree must be discerned by the Luke. 6. 44. fruites, and not euerie one that sayth, Matth. 7. 21. Lord, Lord, but hee that dooth his Fathers wyll which is in heauen, shall inherite it, wee must examine, syfte and trye them once againe, by this note, whether theyr lyues and conuersations be correspondent to theyr calling, which they would pretende: otherwise I see no cause, why not as well then as the false prophetes, of whose fraud and counterfeyt simplicitie, S. Paule gaue warning to the ChurchActs. 20. 30. at Ephesus, they should weare this paynted maske or vizarde. Vt ad ducant discipolos post se, that they maye carrie schollers and disciples after them. For as the Scribes and Phariseis meant neuer worse, nor spake further wide of any rule, then when they declined: the secōd nowne in Grammar, that is Magister in the preface. So Christe our Sauiour, to settle vs from slyding into trappes of slypper guyle, hath sette downe principles, bothe what and howe to iudge: of those that tell vs, Christ is heere and there, which is by scāning of their liues. Beside, he wylleth vs, Operibus credere, to beleeue his workes: and agayne, as it were for example sake, Iohn. 10. 37 not to beleeue him further, then he dyd the workes of his Father. The spyrite of God, was neyther in the 3. Reg. 19. 11 12. mighty winde, that threwe downe bothe hylles and rockes: nor in the styrring, nor in the flame, but in Sibilo aurae tenui, in the gentle breath of ayre, according to that sentence of Iob, Iohn. 4. 16. Vocem aurae leuis audiui, I hearde the voyce, or sounde of a mylde and gentle ayre: the reason is because, Pro. 3. 34. Deludet illusores, & mansuetis dabit gratiam, The scoffers he wyll delude, and giue grace to the meeke and courteous. Eccle. 12. 13. Quis miserebitur incantatori a serpente percusso, who wyll haue pittie and compassion, of an enchaunter that is stoong with a Serpent: for he that Eccle. 13. 1. toucheth pitch shall be defiled. They that are of the fleshe Rom. 8, 5. sauour of thinges fleshlie, and they that are of the spyrite, of things spyrituall, 1. Cor, 2. 14. Animalis homo, non precipit ea quaesunt spiritus Dei: for a carnal mā hath no taste of those thinges, which belong to the spirite. New wine: is Luke. 5. 37. neuer put into foystie bottelles, new garmentes, are not clowted vppe with ragges: neither wyll true wisedome, enter into mindes that are ouerflowne with wickednesse. The principle which was set downe by the blinde men in the Gospell: Iohn. 9. 31. Scimus quod peccatores Deus non audit, we knowe that God wyll heare no sinners, but those onely which heare him and obserue his wyll, maye giue a warning, how farre we maye wade, or proceede in iudgement of these matters. For as an Ospraye can not stare against the Sunne, nor a Buzzarde wyll be trayned to the feeld, nor a mastie brought to followe sent, nor a shepheards curre to raunge or hunt: no more is it possible for a wicked man to reach vnto the prouidence of God, or to atteyne those extraorindarie
fauours, which are inspyred to the godly: wherevppon it was not sayd by Dauid, without purpose, Opus grande esse, 1. Par, 29. 1. non enim homini acquiretur habitatio sed Deo: that it is a peece of worke or weight and moment when a dwelling place, is not appropriate to man, but euen to God himselfe &c. for though the Prophet speaketh of the temple in Ierusalē. yet we may tourne the same with greater reason to our mindes, which are the temples of Gods holy spirite: as S. 1. Cor. 6. 19. Paule hath stilled them, Habenti Matt. 4. 25. enim dabitur &c. for to him that hath a stocke of godlinesse already, more grace shall be giuen, whereas on the other side, Auferetur ab impiis Iob. 38. 15. lux sua, that glims of light which they haue already, shall be taken from the wicked. This was the reason, why the Angell sayde to Esdras, that if he would 4. Esd. 5, 13. faste, weepe, and praye, seuen dayes together, he should vnderstand farre deeper mysteries, then euer he had heard before. Iaco. 3. 17. Quae enim de sursum est sapientia, &c. for the wisedome which commeth from aboue, is full of compassion and good workes: as they that are most pure in heart, beholde God in his glorie. We knowe what Christe sayth, of the Angelles of young chyldren,Matt. 18, 10. which maye be extended to those that are lyke in godlynesse: Cicero discourseth out of Plato verie learnedlie, concerning our abilitie, to looke with iudgement into thinges to come, that when the baser parte of our mindes, wherein neither temperaunce nor wisedome, but luste and appetite beare sway, hath beene chafed and enflamed with excesse of diette, chollor, passion, or such lyke distempers, as obscure the lyght of nature, it bringes nothing foorth, but monsters and fantasticall conceites in sleepe. But when the pride of wanton appetite, is curbed and restrayned by the sharpe bytte of abstinence, and the spirite put in heart againe, by displacing of vniust desires: which from the first beginning, spurned and rebelled against GOD, when the vapours of excesse and surfette, haue beene slaked with the droppes of moderation: Tunc visa occurrunt tranquilla, & veracia, Then meete we, with those calme and certayne dreames, which giue ayme to fortune. Vppon this ground, we reade that many in the state of Lacedemon, not content nor fully satisfied, with their waking cares, would watch and lye abroade in the temple of Pasithea (as I sayd before) without the walles, that no delyght or fancies, might withdrawe theyr mindes, from the scope orIn Acta. homil. 26. obiect of diuinitie. Chrysostome, hating and detesting vtterlye the vaine presumption of that age, affyrmeth notwithstanding, that when men that otherwise liue well, dispose themselues to rest, hauing prayed and fasted a good whyle before, Dulces somni, & visiones mirabiles, sweete sleepes ensew, with visions that are woonderfull. Wherevnto Peter Martyr, giuing as it were a full consent, concludeth, that whosoeuerIn 3. Reg 13 is not wholy sequestred, and retyred from the world, is most vnapt and vnfitte to prophecie. Saint Augustine giues the reason, Quia
Aug. epi. 80 orationes debilitat, caligo et tumultus secularum actionum, because the miste and tumult of affayres, and dealings of the worlde doth weaken and abate the force of prayer, and to the same effecte, is that of S. Paule 2. Tim. 2. 4. No man being a soldier to God, entangleth himselfe wyth seculiar businesse, that he may please him, to whom he hath approoued himselfe. &c.

The monasteries at the first beginning of the Church were freighted full, wyth prophets of the lawfull kynde: and such as were indeede inspyred from aboue, as appeareth by the speeches both of Isaac the munk Iulius Sabba, Simeon and diuers other of that sort, which went aboute in sheepe skinnes, in Goates skinnes, needy, in distresse, afflicted, wandryng8 Heb. 11. 3 Eccl. 37. 19 in desertes, in mountaines and dennes, and in caues of the earth, of whom the worlde was not worthy. We say not that euery soule, but that Anima viri sancti, enunciat aliquando vera, the soule of a godly man reuealeth oftentimes true thynges, and therefore, though many standers by were well enclyned to the sayth, because there were deuoutAct. 1. 5. men of euery nation, that is vnder heauen, yet the spirite rested onely vppon those who from the time of Christ his ascending, had prepared theyr religious and zealous mindes to lodge, and entertaine so diuine a comforter.

The promise was to Saul, that he should not onely prophecye, butReg. 10. 6 Mich. 2. 7. beside Mutari in virum alium, be chaunged into an other kinde of man. And God assureth vs by the Prophet Micheas, that his words shall remayne with those. Qui gradiuntur recte, that walke vprightly. The soyle is blessed by the mouth of God hymselfe, which soking vp theMich. 6. 7. comfortable deawe of grace, bryngeth foorth neyther weedes nor thornes, but Herbam opportunam, his a quibus colitut, sweete grasse and seasonable vnto those by whō it is mannured. Action is the lyfe of sayth (as heate of fire) and looke euen as the body wythers, withoutMac. 2. 26. Ezec. 20 3. the spirite, so dooth fayth wythout charity. God wyll not vouchsase to gyue aunswer to badde men, neyther is it possible for such to be made acquainted with his secretes, as dwell not in hys fauoure. We must therforeEccl. 37. 19 fift our Prophets, whether they call dayly vppon God, to directe them in the course of trueth: whither they can franckly protest wyth Samuel, that they haue robbed no man of his goods, or with S. Paule1. Reg. 8. that they haue abused and circumuented no man. Whither they bee patterns of good workes, and presidents to the faythfull, both in worde and deede, whither they denye themselues with all the vanities, and vnstable2. Cor. 7. 2. Tit. 2. 7. Tit. 2. 12. Tim. 5. 7. pleasures of the worlde and whither they can iustifie themselues before those that are abroade &c. for such were all the blessed Prophets, whose surpassing vertues are emblasoned in the storye of the scriptures.

Abraham is praysed for entegrity of fayth, for pure loue to God, euen
to the sacraficing of hys sonne, for singlenesse of heart, for stedfaste trust, for hospitality for sufferaunce. Moses shy neth for his moonelesse zeale to trueth, and surpassing loue to the flocke of the faythfull, which appeareth notably by this one example that he was willing, rather to bee cassed out of the booke of lyfe, then his country men should feele the stroke of Gods most greeuous indignatiō. He was preserued in the streame by prouidence, warrāted in al his messages by the voyce of heauen & assisted with the gift of miracles. Elias taught the people, whē the storme was at the worst, he multiplyed the charitable widdowes meale and oyle, raysed vppe an other widdowes sonne, confronted princes in a godly cause, destroyed the Balamites, caused two captaines wyth theyr bandes to be striken deade from heauen, and at the time of his departure, with a clocke deuided the waters. Samuel, was called first by a vision, afterwarde he denounced iudgement against all transgressors of the lawe: no man coulde appeach him of the smallest iniury, he frequented the dayly sacrifie, made no difference of personnes in any cause, and afterwarde by Gods greate mercy, was translated into the mount, that he might not see the plagues which were inflicted vppon the people.

Elizeus succeeded faithfully in the place of his predicessor, opposing himselfe with might and maine, against the professed ennemies of God he shooke the Idoles and hill aultars, corrected the mallice of rancke poyson, cured Naaman of his leprosey, discouered the most secrete ambushes, that the king of Siria coulde deuise or plot in his priuy chamber, with many other workes of extraordinary grace, which prooueth from what spryng or fountaine he deriued his authority. The Prophet Esay, albeit he were royally discended, as diuers wryte, abandoned the wanton pleasures and delights of the courte, preferring thornes and crosses of the godly, before garlandes and entising fauours of the reprobate. He was euer at the Princes elbowe, to direct him in the way of trueth, brought him daily messages from the mouth of God, cured hys vlcer, defended the Orphanes, and poore wyddowes, encouraged the saynthearted, made the sonne reuert tenne degrees, which it neuer dyd before nor euer since, and at the length became a Martir. Dauid was a man, selected according to the heart of God, for the mildenesse of his disposition, beside, his iustice and religion were so well accepted in the sight of God, as hys sonne was sorborne the longer, notwithstanding his idolatry. The platforme of the Temple, was cōmitted to his keping, by the hands of God himselfe, wyth euery pinne and nayle that appertayned to the same, and as the woman tolde him, so was he in verye deede, Sapiens sicut angelus dei, discreete and wise like one of Gods angels.

Abdias (as S. Ierome thinkes) for rewarde of hys constant cleauing and adhearing to the preachers of the promise, during the bloudy rage
of Achab and Iesabell, was inspyred wyth the gift propheticall, Et ex duce exercitus, sit dux eclesiae, and of a leader of an armye, became a guyde of the Church &c. Ionas was the sonne of the prophet as some thinke, whom the Prophet Elizeus called backe to lyfe, to showe that God woulde imploy and vse him in the greatest matters: no weather was too scalding for him in the seruice of hys God, he was deliuered by miracle, out of the belly of a mighty Whale, and preached afterwarde repentaunce, and contrition to Niniuie. Abias, was admitted for his vertue, and esteemed so his counsayle. He knewe the wife of Ieroboam, Suggerente spiritu, when she came disguised, and the cause of hee comming before conferrence. Abacuck was snatched vppe by an angell for the releefe of Daniell, and as S. Ierome wrytes, Quasi propheta loquitur, quae futura videt: speaketh like a Prophet, those thinges which hee sees shall follow. The Prophet Zacharie (I meane) the husbande of Elezabeth, Incedebat in omnibus mandatis, walked in all the commandements, Anna the blessed widdow that prophecied of Christ, persisted many yeeres together day and night in prayes and fasting, without departing from the temple. S. Philippes daughters, were inspyred wyth the like gift, and (as Eusebius reports) renouncing all vaine pleasures of the worlde, remayned vergins whyle they lyued. Cornelius, whomlib. 5. ca 22 the angel vouchsafed to visite, feared God wyth all his house, gaue exceeding greate almes to the poore and needy, and persisted in prayer The greatest parte of those, which had the gift of Prophecy, after the time of the Apostles: bare aboute the markes of our Lorde and Sauiour Iesus Christ in theyr bodyes. Policarpus, the sweete Martir of our Lorde, had a certaine dreame or vision not long before his ende, thatTheo. lib. 1. cap. 7. hys bolster fell on fire, which myght eyther signifie & prefigure death or constancie, for suffering the soft pillowes to be burnt, which the wicked (as the Prophet sayes) that they may sincke, more easile and deepely into sinne, sowe to theyr elbowes. But note that first this vision came after fasting, and continuall grones and prayers, powred out both dayEzec. 13. 18 and night, then that the same was presented to a personne of such truth as neuer spake any thing, which came not foorthwith to passe, & lastly that he sealed his report, with the stampe of Marterdome. Potamiena gaue a ce •• aine watch worde to Basilides, one of his cheefest tormentors: tha • ere it were long, by Gods greate mercy and vppon his earnestEuse. lib. 4 cap 1. 4. sute, he should be reconed and admitted into grace (as in deede hee was) but thys virgine, was a mirror of true chastity, and neuer spake worde in thys kinde, tyll the very poynt and moment of her dissolution (as Steuen sawe the heauens open) In like manner God reuealed vnto Constantine, by speciall grace, sundry attempts, and enterpryses of hys ennemies, before euer they were sette in hand, but we must remember, that he was the first Emperour, that resolutely and throughly professed
Christe, planted trueth in the garden of securitie, weeded vp all lyes and heresies euen by the very rootes, encouraged the godly, punishedDe vita constant. lib. 3. cap. 45 the wicked, helde the Church in peace, heaped fauours of beneuolence and bountie, vppon the golden Bishoppes of that age, cutte shorte theyr enimies, and at the last departure out of this lyfe, gaue vppe the ghost in such a mylde and quiet sorte, Vt non mori prudentibus: that to the wise, hee seemed not to dye, but to exchaunge a corruptyble lyfe, with an euerlasting garlande.

Iohn, the Moonke of Egypt, who gaue forewarning and intelligenceTheodo. lib. 5. cap 4. to Theodosius, of all his ouerthwartes, Et sciscitantibus multis, res futuras praedixit▪ and foretolde to many that enquyred thinges that should come to passe, was a man of peerelesse vertue (as the storyes write) sequestred from pleasures of the world, spending his wholeEuseb. lib. • . cap. 36. Confessi. lib. 6. cap. 13. tyme in contemplation. Serapion was able to reporte, the comming of a speedy messenger, that brought the sacrament, whome no man that was in the chamber sawe, but this was after long and heauye penance doone for sacrificing before Idols. Saint Augustines mother, (as himselfe reportes) after a lyfe, ledde many yeeres, in a woonderfull precise and streight degree, receyued comfort in her sleepe, that herHilar. de Trinit. lib. 2 sonne should be conuerted: wherefore, that principle can neuer fayle, that albeit artes, and faculties which are taught by men, maye encrease by exercise, yet other graces, that proceed from God, are multiplied bySocra. lib. 4. cap. 18. mercie, and none are capable of such, saue those that apply the vertue of theyr mindes, to looke vppon the beames by which they were illumynate.

I could producte a golden number of such prophetes, as it pleased God, bothe for aduauncement of his trueth, and reproofe of sinne, to rayse vp in all ages: but it may suffice, that all of them were famous in the world, for theyr puritie of lyfe, and theyr dealings sutable in all degrees, to theyr function. With the wicked prophets it fareth otherwise, for if we lyst to scan the forme and manner, of theyr liues and dealings among men, shal finde, that howsoeuer some of them can shadow their dishonesty with greater sleight then the rest, yet all of them are in effect, as farre from godlynesse, as those other were from errour and iniquitie. Euen one of those Sibillas, which are so much spoken of, confessedEuseb. de vita constāt. in playne termes, then by the folly of her parentes, shee was deuoted to such a kinde of trade, as berefte all modest mindes of shame, and of it selfe was altogether voide of common honestie. A certayne zealous personne, hauing a good wyll to deuide chaffe from corne, by that assured principle of Christe, Whosoeuer wyll lyue godly in Iesus Christe, must suffer persecution, &c. Demaunded of Maximilla, (the false Prophetesse) in the first age of the Church: besides of men, which were brought vp and instructed in the schoole of Montanus, and lykewise
of the women, which beganne to chatte without all moderation. Ecquis optimorum, &c. Whether any of those honest folkes, were euerIdem. lib. 5. cap. 5. persecuted for the trueth, by the Iewes or Infidelles: Nemo certe (no truely (sayth he) not one of them. They rather hanged, drowned, and made away themselues, most lyke to those Circumcellions, against whome Saint Augustine vndertooke to write, proouing that not the manner of the death, but the goodnesse of the cause, giues the crowne of Martyrdome. Againe, in disgrace of such badde Prophets, as withLib. 5 cap. 7. theyr olde wiues tales (as saint Paule hath tearmed them) disturbed, and disordered the peace and quiet of the Church. Apollonius, a learned writer setteth downe, that Montanus, was a great procurer of diuorces, an abolisher of olde fastes, prescribed by the Church, and a setter vp of newe, an exactor of coyne, a taker of bribes for offerings: adding further, that women were no sooner inspyred with his spirite, but foorthwith they ranne away from theyr husbandes, and (as S. Ierome writes) Deserunt viros Helenae sequuntur Alexandres, these Helenes forsakeA. D. Gerōt theyr owne good men, and runne after Alexandres, a meete lyuerie for so badde an occupation. Dyd euer Olda the Prophetesse, the blessed virgin Elyzabeth, or saint Phillips daughters, paynt theyr faces, colour their heaires, weare garish apparell, practise vsurie, or play at the tables. All these good thinges, could Maximilla doo, beside, fathering a false commaundement, vpon our Sauiour Christe▪ as if he had inhibited his Apostles, for the space of twelue yeeres after his ascending vp, to depart from Ierusalem.

The blinde prophetes of Egypt, which enduced Valerian, to persecute and afflict the Church of GOD, fell to the sacrificing of young boyes: Et profundas exercuere praestigias, and practised a straunge kinde of sutteltie or coniuring. The Bishoppes of great Brittayne, obseruedBeda in Histor. Augustines demeanure, with great aduisement: and cheefelie, whether at theyr first approching to his presence, hee were mylde and gentle lyke a Lambe, or raging lyke a Woolfe or Tyger, for by the fruites, bothe men in generall, and Prophetes ought to bee discerned. Abbot Ioachim, of whome some made a woonderfull account (and IMelchior. can. lib. 12. pag 722. esteeme) to be the best learned of that crewe, was woorthily reprooued for his errour, vpon that place of saint Iohn: Ego et pater vnum sumus, as if it ought rather to be vnderstoode of vnitie, then substaunce. And Sauanorola beside his businesse, in practising against the state, beyond the warrant of a Preacher▪ perswaded a young Frier, who for the iustification of his maisters doctrine, was wylling to committee his body to the burning flame, to take the Sacrament in his bosome. I neuer heard of any of these aymers and diuiners, De futuris contingentibus, but had his errour, if a man would hunt for it: for though they worke according to the Serpents guyle, yet they want the Dooues simplicitie.
By this we learne, that though the name of Christe, be ryfe in diuerse of theyr mouthes, because (as saint Augustine writes) no man dares endeuour, to abuse in these dayes, Nisi nomine coopertus christiano, vnlesse he be couered and vayled at the least, with the tytle of a christian: yet when they lyue not as they teach, that maxime of the ciuill lawes, must of force take place, Protestationem actui, contrariam non releuare.

FVrthermore, we must obserue, that a • the fayth of holy Prophetes was more strong, theyr conuersation more honest, and theyr words more playne, then those of the false: so was the manner of theyr dealinges, farre more bolde and confident. They neuer shruncke out of the beatē way, for feare of any storme, they regarded neither blast, nor thunderbolte of penall lawes: but alwayes set theyr faces, with a gallant courage against sinne, esteeming lyttle with what rigour, or extremitie they were intreated at the handes of mortall Kinges, so long as the message with which they were cheefely put in trust, were presentedExo. 5. 1. as it ought to be. Moses was not afrayde to delyuer his opinion in bolde wordes, so often as it pleased GOD to employe, or vse him in that charge. Samuell forbare not to recount to Saule, the sharpest tydinges that could come, which were that the kingdome should be rent1. Re. 15. 28. and torne away, bothe from him and his off-spring. Elias, pronounced to the face of Achab, that onely hee and his house, disturbed the3. Re. 18. 18. peace of Israell: in respect whereof, not one of them should be lefte, to pysse against a wall, much lesse, to swaye the Scepter of imperiall3. Reg. 16. 2. aucthoritie. Iehu, reprooued Baasa to the teeth, though by this meane of a Prophet, he became a Martyr.
