Elias, openly professed himselfe to be the onely Prophet, whome it pleased God to reserue, for the ministerie3, Re. 18. 2 • . of his Church in Israell: and againe, hee was desyrous that Naaman should repayre to him, for cure of his disease, that all the world maye4. Reg. 18. •
see, what slender force the deuyll, or his kinde haue had to roote vppe true Prophecie. Thus dealt Nathan with Dauid, Esay with Ezechias, Ieremy with Sedechias, Saint Iohn the Baptist with Herode, Christe2. Cor. 4. 2. 1. Tim. 3. 7. 2. Cor. 8. 2 ••
with Pylate; Paule with Agrippa, Isaac with Iulian, Chrysostome with Eudoxia, Symeon with Valerius, Iohn with Theodisius: and the rest of this good sorte, according to the cyrcumstaunce of the tymes, and personnes, where they ledde theyr lyues and tooke charge, bothe helde2. Pet. 2. 19. a stedfast conscience to GOD, and lefte a good report among the people. The fourmer worde of saynt Peter, wyll sende out beames from vnderneath a bushell, and giue lyght in the darke, which propertie encouraged that woorthy Appollonius, to sende out challenges, toEuseb lib. 5. cap. 17. all false prophets, wheresoeuer they were bredde, that eyther durst presume to trust themseles, or would haue credite in the world, Vt venirent in 〈1 page missing〉

ANother circumstaunce ought diligently to be noted and regarded in this cause, that is, whither they that challeng the gift of prophecy aboue the rest, and will be counted prophets in the world, apply theyr knowledge to the profite of themselues, or to the glory of God, and comfort of the faythfull. I haue specifyed how scrupulous the ministers and angels of God were euer in accepting any kinde of reuerence from men, that might detract or draw one iotte from the diuine prerogatiue. Wherevnto we may adioyne the warinesse of Daniel who fearing least Dan. 2. 30. the people might aduaunce him, any poynt aboue his ordinary pitch, assured them before hand, that misteries were nor reuealed, in respect of more great and ample measure of discretion, or wysedome that was in him. For whosoeuer speaketh of himselfe seeketh Ioh. 7. 18. hys owne glory, but he that seeketh the glory of him that sent him, is true, and in hym resteth no kinde of iniustice. What are we (sayth S. Paule) 1. Cor. 4. 2 but ministers of Christ, and dispensers of his misteries? and 1. Cor. 3, 6. againe, his ministers in whom you haue beleeued, we consist not of a nature more diuine and excellent then other men, as diuers thought, that would haue honoured Paule and Barnabas, in stedde of Act. 14. 11 Iupiter and Mercury. We differ not in substaunce (sayth Clem. rec. 65. lib. 4. S. Clement) but in professiō and godlines, we store and hoorde vp no treasure in these earthen vesselles 2. Cor. 4. 7 Vt sublimitas sit virtutis dei, et non ex nobis, that the excellency may be of the power of God, and not of vs &c. The Prophet Moses was so carefull, both of his country and for the church of Christ, and so reckelesse of hys owne perticuler, as for theyr sake he wyshed to(v) Exo. 30. 32. be cassed out of the (u) booke of life. I am the man (sayth Dauid) that haue 2. Re. 24, 17. sinned, and dealt naughtily, these sily sheepe haue not committed any fault, and therefore let thy wrath be tourned against mee and my fathers house. And Paul himselfe wished to be Rom. 9. 3. Anathema from Christ for his brethren, which were his kins-men according to the flesh &c. This onely difference there is, that when it came to resolution, whither Moses would take charge of greeued and afflicted men, or become a byrd of Pharaos nest, he preferred the disgrace Heb. 11. 25 of Israell before the wealth of Egypt. And when Paule coulde not please God(a) Ioh. 3. 11. without offence to men, he forsooke all for the gospel. Christ cōmaunded the diseased men, that had beene cured at his hande: to make no (a) noyse or brute abroade, but to depart in silence, when the people sought to crowne hym like a monarke of the world, (whose pryde is no parte of eternall glory) he gotte vppe to the Ioh. 6. 3. mountaines. Beside, if Ioab durst not depriue his maister of the credite and honour, of surprising a certaine towne called Abela by anticipation, 2. Re. 12. 28, Ne nomini suo ascriberetur victoria, least the victory might haue been ascribed to himselfe, howe much lesse may we presume, to vaunt or glory
which indeede (as S. Paul saies) haue nothing of our owne, but what we haue 1. Cor. 4. 7 receiued.

The same Apostle, beeing vrged, and as it were enforced, for the credite of the message which he brought, to tell what had beene reuealed to himselfe by extraordinarie fauour, vseth such a kinde of bashfull speeche and vtteraunce, notwithstanding in these wordes, Noui hominem, I knewe a certayne man: againe, Siue 2. Cor. 12, 2. in corpore, siue extra corpus, Whether in the body, or without the body. Furthermore, transferring the certayne knowledge, of the secrete from himselfe to God: and last of all, not so much as touching it, tyll foureteene yeeres complete and ended, after the thing was doone, as a man may readily discouer his spirite, to haue been Apostolique and holy. Much after the same manner, Saint Iohn the Enangelist suppressing his owne name, altogether in all matters that concerne himselfe: vseth none other tytle then of the Disciple, whome Iesus Iohn. 13, 23. looued, Moreouer, it is holden for a principle, by saint Paule in another place, that whosoeuer thinketh him selfe to be Gal. 6, 5. something, where he is nothing in verie deede, standeth in his owne lyght, and is verie much abused: and for feare least Paule himselfe, might be too much 2. Cor. 12, 7. extolled or puffed vp, with the greatnesse of reuelations, an angell of Sathan was sent to buffet him. The Angell would not abyde to be adored (by saint Iohn) in respect hee was his fellow seruaunt: for Lact. de fal. sap. since it is theyr office to giue attendance vpon the wyll of God, and theyr greatest honour consisteth in the seruice, which they doo before his Throne, it is most farre from theyr intent, to challenge any thing that may depriue or robbe him of his glorie: And therefore is it well sayd, by Malachie, Mala. 16. Si ego Deus, vbi honor? If I be GOD, where is my honour? And againe, by Esaye, that heEsay. 42, 8. wyll not resigne his glorie to another. I wyll not stand vppon the quoting, and repeating of a multitude of places, whereby wee may be taught, how fitte it is to detracte, as much as may be from our owne presumption, and adde it to the fauour of almighty God, and neuer to respect the paynting of our plumes, when wee striue about attayning grace: for by this lyttle we may finde, that whosoeuer vaunteth of any good thing, that descendeth not from aboue, hath not the spyrite of God, but of Lucifer, neyther is a Prophete but an hypocrite.

The same course haue the Prophetes euer holden, touching wealth: for Golde is but an excrement of earth, and therefore vnfitte to bee weighed, or ballaunced with an ornament of Paradise. Abraham, would receyue no kinde of present from the king of Sodome, least hee might be thought, to haue beene the Gene. 14, 32. richer by his lyberalitie. Saule was commaunded, to 1. Reg. 13, 3. reserue no scrappe nor parcell of the spoyle, that was withdrawne from Amleack. Samuel, the blessed Prophete of almightie God, tooke a solemne othe that he had neuer 1. Reg. 12, 3. gleaned, nor
embeaseled the value of a myte, that belonged to his neighbour. The Prophete which brought tydings of the notable discomfiture of Bennadad, was charged not to eate one crust of breade, nor drinke one cup of water by the waye: which charge, because he 3. Reg. 13, 8. brake and violated in the house, and by the meane of a false Prophete, a Lyon rushed vnawares out of the desart, & deuowred him. Elizeus, could not be perswaded, to take so much 4. Reg. 5, 15. as a frayle of figs or reysons. Nor Acts. 8, 18. Peter, and Iohn, of Simon Magus, for the gyft of myracles. Iudas himselfe, hauing somewhat better thought vppon the horrour, of his owne most execrable villany, in selling his deere maister for thyrtie pence, flong them to the Matth. 27, 3. Phariseis, in a hanging rage, neyther durst the Phariseis themselues (howe greatly soeuer they reioyced in the deede) bestowe them, in the common Matth. 27, 6. treasure of the Church, because they were the price of bloud, &c. We reade in deede, that saint Philippe kept open house and Acts. 21, 8. hospitalitie, for all the workemen in Gods blessed haruest, but not that any parcell of his wealth, was gotten by the prophecies of his daughters.

We maye saye the lyke of Num. 24, 13 Balaam, who reiected a ritch brybe, of Debora, of Nathan, Dauid, Olda, Agabus, &c. which spake by lawfull warrant of the holy Ghost, and confirmed theyr conceytes by sounde aucthoritie. They knewe well enough, who commaunded his Disciples, Matth. 10, 8. Quae gratis accepissent, & gratis dare, to giue freely, what they had receyued freely: and whose principle it was lykewise, that it was a more Acts. 20, 35. blessed thing to giue, then to receyue. They were not ignoraunt, what oddes there was betweene Prou 23, 23. purchasing and selling trueth, that God delyghteth not in 1. Par. 19, 7. gyftes, that no wise man, wyll pricke his fingers among thornes, whereas no Roses are to be gathered: that Bishoppes ought not to be sharpe and 1. Tim. 2, 4. eager vpon gayne, nor feede the flocke for regarde of 2. Tim. 2, 3. benefites: but of their owne accorde, nor labour for reward in this vncertayne lyfe, where so many thystles growe, to choke the seedes of trueth, & which seldome prosper in a feeld of fortune. This was the cause why Christe taught his Disciples, Mark. 6, 8. Nudos volare, that is to strippe themselues before they tooke theyr flight: Ne Hieron. ad Exuper. auri deprimerentur pondere, least otherwise they might be depressed by the weight of treasure. The wordes which saynt Peter and saynt Iohn vsed to the seely crypple, at the gate of the Temple which is called beawtifull: Acts. 3, 8. Aurum & argentum non habemus, were not ouercast with so fayre a flourishe to the carnall sence of man, as those of Iudas, Quid Matt. 26, 15. vultis mihi dare, what wyll you giue mee, were vttered with a delyghtfull harmony: but those which sounded worst restored strength, and those that pleased best gaue a fee Acts. 1, 18. to the gallowes. Saint Paule was so farre, from seeking to enrich himselfe by sacred gyftes and offices, as because he would be 2. Cor. 11, 9. chargeable
to none, he laboured with his 1. Cor. 4. 2. owne proper hands. He could not endure the smallest blaste of vaine glorie, & though he knew by warrant of Gods word, that they which serue 1. Cor. 9, 13. the Aultar, are to lyue vppon the same: yet he renounced all his interest and lybertie, and was afrayde to temper with the baytes and lymetwigs 1. Tim. 6, 11. of gayne: least eyther they might take holde of his winges, or abuse his disposition. When the Queene of Iberes, Socr. lib 1. cap. 7. would haue rewarded the good captyue with large presentes, which in the name of Iesus had recouered his sonne: shee transferred all the merite from her selfe to Christ, desiring only that the Queene by sauing her own foule, would be thankfull vnto him, that was the aucthor of so great a benefite▪ Liberius, the godlie Bishop would not accept, one Theod. lib. 2 cap. 16. crowne of all those which were sent him from Constans that wicked Emperour, in the name of a francke gyft or beneuolence. The zealous Moonkes, which were haled and dregged out of theyr celles, by Theophilus the Bishop of Alexandria, to minister & serue in his Church: finding the sayd Bishop, Vitam in Socr. lib. 6. cap. 7. pecunia facienda conterere, to spende the full course of his lyfe, in making summes of money, would abyd no longer in his iurisdiction. It is most certayne, which Tacitus setteth downe, Annal. lib 4 Res virtute melius, quam pecunia stare, that thinges prosper much better, by vertue then by coyne, whereas they are woont to lye most (sayth De falsa sap. cap. 4. Lactantius) that couette wealth and hunt for gayne: Quae res proculdubio a sanctis prophetis abfuit, which thing (sayth he) without all doubt was most far from holy Prophetes: Wherefore not vnto vs, O Lord, not vnto vs, but to thy blessed name be all honour and glorie. The wicked take gaine, to be perfect 1. Tim. 6, 5. godlinesse, they spare Acts. 20. 29. not the flocke, they speake peruerse thinges, onely to Acts, 20, 30. drawe Disciples after them. They seeke Iohn. 5, 44. glorie at anothers hande, and not from GOD alone, they followe those thinges which Phil. 2, 21. concerne themselues, and not Christe Iesus, they defend it as a principle, Oportere etiam, vnde cunque Sap. 15, 12. ex malo acquirere, that we may snatch on all sides by naughty meanes, and why so? because (sayth saynt Iohn. 12, 43. Iohn) they haue looued the glorie of men more then of GOD, hazarde then securitie. mandragora, then holynesse, a messe of redde ryse pottage, then lyfe euerlasting. And as Origine writeth vppon the booke of Orig. in Numb. Numbers, wee enquire no more after such kindes of men, because they haue the lotte of Dathan and Abiron, that is, the earth hath swallowed them: wherefore it is not noted, as the meanest blessing, amonge those which it pleased God, to sende to Salomon for Dauids sake, that golde and siluer bare no price in his dayes, for, so long as mens eyes are daseled with a golden sunne, it wyll be somewhat hard to staye the greedie mindes, of many from desiring that which is not lawfull. They which came to the Prophete Balaam for aduise, brought with them in theyr handes, Num. 22. 7. Diuinationis praetium, the rewarde of his diuination. The Leuite professed vnto Micheas, that he was content to serue, but it should be, Iud. 1, 19. Vbi sibi vtile fore prospexisset: where he founde it, for his
greatest benefite. The sonnes of Heli, were such Prophets as these, gleaning 1. Reg 2, 14. daylie from the people, which repayred with a zealous heart and well affected minde, to the daylie sacrifice: and the sonnes of Samuel 1. Reg. 8, 3. lykewise, who notwithstanding the religious example of theyr father, declyned into greedinesse, receiued brybes, and peruerted iudgement. In this rancke, we may marshall Gieze, who was at all that his maister had refused: those false Prophetes lykewise, which in the dayes of Micheas, Mich. 3, 11. Diuinabant in pecunia, prophecied for money. The Pythonisse, which is affirmed Acts. 16, 16. Magnum quaestum praestitisse, Dominis suis diuinando, to haue procured great gayne to hir Lords by prophecie. The Malcontentes at Rome, which (as Liuie showes) Liui. lib. 7. Nouos ritus sacrificandi vaticinando, inferebant in domos: brought new rytes of sacrificing into priuate houses, to the peryll of the state, made theyr profite of young mindes, abused by the vanities of superstition, vnder the maske of prophecy▪ Among these may we recken the soothsayers and whysperers, who gathered so fast at Rome, as the Senat was gladde to sette downe an order at the last, that none but gentlemen should apply those matters, least so diuine an arte might be wrested from the maiesty of religion to the seruitude of cousinage. Among these, we may not omitte 1. Tim. 4. 10 Demas, who forsooke Christe for the worlde, nor Natalius, who for fifty shillingas was hyred to discharge the deuty of a Euse. lib. 5. cap. vlt. byshoppe among hetetickes. Moreouer the glozing prophets, which in the tyme of Ireneus (as himselfe reportes) when Cont. Val. lib. 2. ca. 58. the church was luke warme with the bloud of Christ, were wont for gaine Occulta hominum in apertum proferre, to bring to light the secretes of mens hearts. And Montanus also, who being puffed vppe with a winde of glory, first made a close compact with Euse. lib. 5 cap. 15. Sathan notwithstanding former vowes and promises to God, and afterwarde began to prophecy. To conclude, of thys kynde are the Prophets of thys tyme, who feeding vpon follies of our minde, as a scabbe dooth vppon noisome humors of the body, gleane away the thrist of simple men, and eate vppe sily wyddowes wyth houses. Belike they are of the same mynde whereof Nipos was, in saint Ieroms time, they beeleeue wyth that prating iacke Seruetus, whom Caluine put to death, for heresie at Geneua, or with the Libertines, that all the stedfast promises of grace and fauoure, which were made by Moses at the publishing and setting foorth of the lawe, should be performed in thys lyfe, for otherwise they would not set drosse to sale in stedde of golde, nor ballace empty vessels with vnlawfull merchandise. By thys therefore wee learne, what to deeme of those that will not pleade but for a fee, nor gyue warning without wages.

NOwe let vs pose them once againe with hys demaunde, whither the false prophets of thys age, agree together in theyr aimes, for thys note Paule embraceth as the rest, publishing in all the churches that God was not the God of disorde, 1. Cor. 14. 33. but of vnity. Againe, he will haue all
men to be perfect in our 1. Cor. 12. 25 knowledge, and one kinde of vnderstanding▪ and to speake one trueth, as Christ himselfe woulde haue hys disciples noted, and distincted by this speciall Ioh. 13. 35. property of louing one another. God promiseth by Ezechiell to hys Eze. 11. 9. Cor vnum one heart, wherunto Via vna, one way is added Ier. 32. 39. also by Ieremy, & bothe are monuments of truth, and pledges of his fauour. Before any man presumed to build towers vp to heauen, the worlde was (b) Terra vnius labii, et eorundem sermonum, a lande of one lippe and of one language. At the first beginning of the Church, when the graces of Gods holy spirite were most plentifull, there was but one Act. 4. 32 heart, and one soule among all the beleeuers, they were(k) Gen. 11. 2. of one 2. Cor. 12. 8. conceyte in all thinges, and helde together in one lincke of 2. Cor. 13. 11 Philip. 2. 2. charity. They gaue order for the cutting Gal. 5. 12. of those off, which went about to disturbe thys golden meane, which is the Col. 3. 15. bonde of perfection, and the cheefest spectacle whereby we may Heb. 12. 13 see God in his glory: vpon these premisses, S. Paule might be bolde to conclude the church of Corinth to be 1. Cor. 3. 3. carnall. For where as there is amongst you strife and emulation are you not carnal sayth he, Ergo no Prophets. 1. Cor. 2. 13. Animalis enim homo, non percipit ea quae sūt spiritus dei, for the sēsual or carnal mā (sayth the same Apostle) perceiueth not those thinges, which are of the spirite of God &c. with whom S. Iames agrees in euery point, affirming that kinde of wisedome not to descende from the father of light, but to be Iac 3. 14. Terrenam annimalem, diabolica, in earthly, sensual or diuelish. So long as it pleased God to deliuer oracles, 4. Re. 17. 3 Per manus omnium videntium et prophetarum, by the handes of all the seers and the prophets, they were alwayes founde in tune, and ready (as Lactantius reportes) to iustifie themselues by one assured grounde and with one voyce, De Ori. err. lib. 2. cap 8. whych S. Paule calleth Rom, 12. 16 Idipsum inuicem senire, in so much as neyther the Carpocratians coulde finde any iarre among the fathers, nor Euse. lib. 5 cap. 13. Apelles any discorde in the Canon. But among the counterfeites aswell in thys as other notes sette downe before, it is farre otherwise for as they byte at euery bubble that aryseth in a troubled water, so Chrisostome noteth, that they square and vary not only from the lawfull pastors of the church: but euen among theyr owne fraternities, as for example Ephraim from Manasses, Annas from Caiphas, Herod from Pilate, one fretting and stinging one an other, like a generation of vipers, &c. till themselues be consumed, and thys is the very best end that can be looked for of deuision, eyther among holy men or aboute holy matters. When Deiotarus and Cotta, beganne to lay theyr heads together, about the formes and plots of theyr prophecy: good Lord sayth one, what a difference and oddes were betweene theyr rules, Vt Cicero. de diuine. quaedam plane essent contraria, so as some of them were most plainly contrary, and in an other place, the same author witnesseth, alias gentes(&) Gal. 5. 15. aliter signa interpretatas, that some countryes expounded these thinges, in a diuerse sorte from others, wherevppon we may note, that theyr diuination consisted not in the vertue of the thing it selfe, but in the flourish of
their owne imaginations. The Poets and Prophets as we find in Plutarch, could neuer be sette in one tune together, in recommending of the credite of Apollos Oracles, neyther can we reade of any concorde or agreement, betweene the Prophetes, which were euer whyspering in the eares of Silla and Marius. Caesar and Pompey, Octauius and Antony, sauing when the packe was sette among the crafty knaues, to deceiue all parties. Furthermore the diuersity of grounds, or principles wherevpon the Painims built theyr sencelesse hopes, was thought by Socrates, to be the greatest cause of theyr debate, though in very deede there was trueth in neyther side. I haue spoken somwhat before in my discourse against Astrologie, concerning the fowle cōtradictions, between Astrologers, about the faces, signes, gouernors, aspects, &c. the lyke are dayly seene among the coniurers, which shotte by the deuils ayme, and therefore it is tyme to checke thysGen. 16. 4 ietting Agar, which despiseth her olde dame the church and spouse of Christ, & to shaue off the lockes & pare the nayles of thys Egyptian damsell, which falles to skinnishing and scratching of the Prophets, althoughDeu. 21. 12. she can preuayle no more against an armie marshalled in order, then the Madianites (qui mutua caedese truncabant) or foolysh knyghtes ofIud. 7 Cadmus, which neuer gaue ouer fighting amonge themselues so long as any one was left aliue to mayntayne the quarrell. Many gaue in euidence against our Sauiour Christ (sayth S. Marke) Sed conuenientia, non erant testimonia, but there was no concorde or agereement inMar. 14. 56. theyr testimonies. The wicked Iudges in Daniell, deliuered the worst against Susanna they could deuise, but theyr tales were no more lyke, thenDan. 13. 36. a Pomgranet and a Mulbery. So fareth it with our Prophets for though they seeme by chaunce sometime to consent, and agree together, it is but after the manner of Sampsons Foxes, whych were tyed by the tayles, and disseuered by heades, that is vnited in lust and deuided in iudgement. Quoties enim repetunt, toties variant, for so often as they repeate theyr aunswers (sayth S. Augustine) so often doo they choppe and alter them. One Schisme fell out among the Pharasies, about the power wherebyIoh, 5. 6. Christe wrought his miracles: another about the baptime of S. Iohn, whether it were from heauen or not, and a thyrd, more bytter then both those, touching the rysing of the dead. Some Prophetes were of a mynde that Ierusalem should perish and lye waste, others that it should flourisheMar. 11. 30. Act. 23. 8▪ and be restored to the former glory, and as no man almost can keepe so badde a dyet, but some mountebancke or other wyll allowe, so no course can be vndertaken, so farre wyde from probable and likely groundes, whereto the deuill is not ready by one pursuiuaunt or other, to gyue a quicke encouragement, which prooues no lesse that consent is a badge of trueth, then that discorde is an eare marke of vncertainty. Pithagoras deriued all sortes of vertues Ab vnitate, which vnder a vayle imported God, supposing the same to be free from all spottes and steynes, and Christe desireth also that hys disciples may be knowne by thys, for though some lauish
and wanton hounds may chaunce sometime to quest without a cause, though the surest archer may sometyme shoote awry and Nathan the Prophet might be forsaken by the spirit for that time, wherin he affirmed vntoSocra. lib. 4. cap. 21. August. Epist. 106. Dauid that he should builde the temple vnto God, &c. yet where a full consent and cry of all the Prophets, Apostles, fathers &c. is resounded in one voyce or tune, we may be sure the chase is not farre off, and wythall accept the same, as a certaine warrant of hys worde, who (as S. Augustine wrytes) in Cathedrā vnitatis doctrinam posuit veritatis, who hath planted the doctrine of trueth in the chayre of vnity.

THe last note, whereby I coulde wish that Prophets should haue theyr finall examination, is set downe from the mouth of God himselfe, inDeut, 18. 21. the playnest manner: let thys be your signe sayth God, whatsoeuer the Prophet speaketh, yf it come not afterwarde to passe, I speake it not, but the Prophet inuented it, by swelling and puffing of his minde &c. and therefore be not thou afrayde of him. Againe Propheta qui vaticinatus estIere. 28. 9. pacem▪ &c, The Prophet which is truely sent from God, may be discerned by this note, whither after he haue prophecied of peace, his word take effect or not &c. for I speake (sayth God) and what worde soeuer I hauePsal. 115. 11 vttered, shall come to passe, and agayne, though all men be lyets, yet my worde which passeth from my mouth, shall not returne voyde, or wythoutEsay. 55. 11. effect to me, Sed faciet quae cunque volui, et prosperabitur in his ad quae misi illud, but shal worke whatsoeuer pleaseth me, & prosper in those thynges to which I haue appointed and directed it. A wise man will not trust a glasse that representeth a straunge face, much lesse a cogging ProphetSocra. lib. 5. cap. 19. 3. Re. 17, 24. that telleth of straunge fortunes, Vt enim quisque optime comicit, ita optimus propheta haberi debet, for as men ayme and coniecture best, so goes the credite of theyr Prophecie.

The widdowe of Sareptha, finding her sonne restored vnto lyfe againe,3. Reg. 22, 18 concluded, Ab effectis: that by this shee was assured that hee was a man of God, and his word preuayled in his mouth, &c. Micheas, hauing been condemned to imprisonment (with the bread of care & water of affliction) by the King: was content to be discredited for euer, and accounted as a carrierEsai. 41. 23. of tales and lyes, if the King returned with his lyfe from the battell. Annūtiate quae ventura sunt in futurum, & dicemus quia dijestis vos: Tell vs. (sayth God by Esay) what things shall come to passe heereafter, and we wyl saye that you are gods▪ whereby it is apparent, that no iudgement can be giuen of the Prophets skyll, before proofe be made of his abilitie. The Samaritan,Iohn. 4. 19. would not acknowledge Christe to be a Prophete, tyll he had discouered her state, and reuealed matters which she supposed to haue been aboue mans reach: And to the same effect S Paule declareth, that the simple man, which entering into the Church where the Prophetes are, findeth the1. Cor. 14. 25 deepest secretes of his hart reuealed, wyll fall downe prostrate, and confesse that God is among them. It is reported in the prayse of Ieremy, that whatsoeuerIere. 32. 24. he spake tooke effect: and for proofe thereof, it cannot be denied,
that so soone as he had giuen warning to the people, that they should perishe with the sworde, the slaughter came vpon them. After that Elizeus,Iere. 38, 2. had giuen cōfort to the people, when the dearth was at the worst, that they should eate and leaue, the plentie and aboundaunce which came after seemed4. Rc. 4, 44. woonderfull. The reason why Saule repayred rather vnto Samuell, then any other for aduise: was because, Quicquid loquiretur sine ambiguitate veniret, whatsoeuer he did speake came to passe without ambiguitie.1. Reg. 10, 9. And surelie, no man had better meanes of noting, and obseruing this rule afterward, then he: for after the Prophete had pronoūced sentence against1. Reg. 15, 26 him and his off-spring, they neuer prospered. The Prophete Ahias, had no sooner delyuered his opinion to the wife of Ieroboam, touching the taking3. Reg. 4, 7. Matth. 8, 13. of her chylde away: and Christe to the Centurion, about the curing of his sonne, but one gasped, and another recouered in that verie minute. When the Prophete called foorth a Lyon, to deuoure his fellow, for refusing to strike at the warning of almightie God, the beast was ready at a3. Re. 20. 36. beck, and the man distracted and torne in peeces, for contempt and breach of duety. Nothing can be sayd, lesse probably in the iudgement and conceyt of man: then that the bloud of a King or Queen should be lycked vp3. Reg. 16. 15 with dogges▪ cōsidering the great care & dilligence (which as appeareth by that plaine example) King of Asa, is vsed about spicing and embawming of theyr bodies, and yet, the sentence of the Prophete was fulfilled, Iuxta verbum3. Reg. 21, 15 Domini, quod loquutus suerat, &c. Whether diuerse of king Ezechias his chyldren, were not made Eunuches in the court of Babylon, as the prophete4. Re. 20, 18. tolde, let the Scriptures testifie. The Iewes themselues, comparing those sharpe plagues which chaunced to Ierusalem: a good whyle after Christe had warned them, what sorowes were to come, beganne to thinke better of his calling. The faithfull, helde the Prophete Agabus in such aActs. 11, 27. sound conceyt, as after he had certainly forwarned, of a pyning dearth that should ensew: they layd their pursses together. & prouided in good time, against the dreadfull weapon of necessitie. The schoolemaister of Antioch had no sooner pronounced what should become of Iulian, but he was arestedTheod. lib. 3 cap. 19. by the mase of prouidence, to aunswer for his bloudy slaughters, in the court of condemnation: insomuch, as another of his sort was able to determine, of the certayne minute wherein that sauadge and wylde boore, which had beene so long rowting in the vineyard of Christe, should aunswere the price of his tyrranny. Another godly Moonke, was so stedfastlie perswaded, that God would not breake the word which he had bothe warranted,3. Re 22. 18. and reuealed by his Prophetes: as not much vnlyke that rare example of Micheas, he engaged his owne body vpon this poynt, that the tyraunt Valens should returne no more, vnlesse hee first enlarged the good Bishoppes, which were then disgraced, and in pittifull enduraunce, for preferringTheo. lib. 4. cap. 3. religion before innouation, and trueth before flattery. For those thinges which are reuealed to the Saintes, are, Grandia & firma, whereas the fables which are coyned in the forge of Sathan, and obtruded to the
credulous, for theyr owne mishappe, are bothe, Vana & vacua. What theIere. 33, 3. lawfull Prophetes sayd, was euer true. What Zedechias, Pashur, Semeias. Simon Magus, and the rest sette downe eyther melted, and dissolued into smoake, or fell out to the contrarie. Their blessinges, were euer turned into curssinges, theyr fayre weather into storme, theyr hope into despayre, their expectation into emptinesse, their mirth into mourning: and howsoeuer they desired to disperse abroade, and giue out Placentia, that is, imaginations to please: yet their happe was neuer (if it were not by meere chaunce) to delyuer, Vera, that is, sound reasons, to perswade, or edifie.

When Montanus and Maximilla were most forward, in making men afrayde with shaddowes, and perplexities of mishappes to come. EusebiusLib. 5. ca. 15. reporteth that not onely forraine warres and troubles were at a styll, which was not seene in a long tyme before, Sed & ipsis christianis, stabilis & secura pax permanfit: but the christians themselues, remayned in a stableSocr. lib. 7. cap. 18. and secure tranquilitie. Alemandurus, a false Prophete, tooke vpon him to assure the Persian, that he should conquere Rome, but himselfe was there most shamefully discomfited. When the false Prophetes, in the dayes of Micheas, were not ashamed to crye out alowde: Dominus in medio nostrū non venient super nos mala, God is in the myddest of vs, and no misfortunesMich. 3, 8. shall come ouer vs, &c. Gladius peruenit vsque ad animam, the sword pierced, to the verie soules of them. By this we finde, that not that spirite, Qui ferebatur super aquas, which was carried vpon the waters: butGene. 1, 2. the glosing spirite, which dwelt in the mouthes of Achabs counsaylours, possesseth, bothe the tongues and hearts of those false Prophets, which delyght in lyes, and the moodes of other simple menne, who make proude fooles, more obstinate and glorious, by too great facility to be seduced. So, many reasons and examples, of the swaruing of false Prophetes, and theyr distressefull endes, haue beene set foorth before, as I wyll brefely conclude with Papias, a true Pastour of the first and purest age, that we must not giue fayth, or credite vnto Prophetes, which hobbe and roue at all aduentures: but determine vpon certayne grounds, not to those, which alwayes seeke to please our humour, but to refourme our liues, not to those, whoseEphe 4, 14. Iud. 12. finall scope is glorie, but edification. Last of all, not to those, Qui circum ferūtur omni vento doctrinae, which are carried about, with euerie puffe of doctrine: but grounded vppon that stedfast rocke of trueth, which is impregnable.

Thus, haue I brought a long and tedious labour to an ende, whereby although I reape none other benefite, then of satisfaction to the world, together with mine owne discharge, from friuolous and fonde conceytes without colour: yet it shall content mee, and perhappes auayle me in the sight of GOD, to haue employed my skyll, and bent my slender force, to the raysing and defacing of the battlementes of this wicked Babel, of confused hopes, which leadeth tyckle subiectes, not onely from consent in language, as the fourmer dyd, whose toppe aspyred to the clowdes: but, to
diuision in obedience and loyaltie, a • Lucifer began, tyll he were cutte off by iustice, and east downe to the bottome. If any other person whatsoeuer, haue a meaning, to dispute the matter vppon bettergroundes, it may suffice: that eyther this which I haue layde together, shall encrease his store, or lyke a thresholde in the porche of the Temple, rayse him somewhat neerer to the poynt, or at the least expresse a meaning in my selfe, to haue perfourmed more, if eyther knowledge had beene correspondent to desire, or vtteraunce to deuotion. God of his greatmercie graunt vs all, the spirite of obedience, and conformitie to his blessed wyll, that howsoeuer, fortunes • osse or alter in this transitorie world, we may fixe our anchers in the comfort of his tender care, and possesse our soules in patience, atteining after many frights and feares of shypwrack, to that porte of euerlasting rest, which neyther can be disturbed by the stormes of pride, nor barred by the sandes of emulation. For, when all is doone, the glorie of this lyfe is but a blaste, and they that couette more on earth, then falleth to the lotte of theyr vncertayne state, shall be depriued of a greater happynesse in the ioyes to come, which are prepared for the chosen.

div.closer: Absolutum, in nomine sanctae, & indiuiduae Trinitatis, Iunii. Sexto.
